orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Orville Daniels
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: April 15, 2011

OD: So, anyway, we had that team going and the next critical part of it was to sell the program to the Chief of the Forest Service because what we wanted was that this be an official program sanctioned by the Chief so that it could be replicated elsewhere and so forth and quite frankly you could not do wilderness fire management without Chief’s approval. So, we took the program back to the Washington office. Once we had thrashed it out and decided what the prescriptions would be and where the prescriptions were applied on the ground we flew back, Bob Mutch and I, to sell the program. And selling is the right word, and we went to the Chief of staff and, you know, there are a lot of memories with that. We went to the Congressional offices and talked to them. We did a whole bunch of preparing the soil for people to accept this concept. And I’ll never forget the most telling personal account that occurred during that and we were, we were, we were presenting it to the Chief of Staff and I believe his name was Buckum, he was the Associate Chief for Research, and he said we need to get behind this program and he said because of all of those big old yellow-bellied ponderosa pine that need to be preserved we need to get behind this program because fire management will keep those going and so forth and so forth. McIntyre, I’m trying to get the Chief’s name at that time, McGuire, John McGuire. John McGuire was also a researcher who came into the research but John was a really great Chief. I would put him at that time as being the best of the modern chiefs. He really, really understood and his comment was he said well, you know, you’re right about those trees but that’s not the purpose here. The purpose here is to maintain the ecosystem mechanisms, not develop yellow-bellied pine. And I thought yaaaaah we got it. I mean that was so, to hear the Chief of the Forest Service put it so succinctly that we needed fire for the ecological purposes of fire in the wilderness that you knew you were going to make it. And we got approval and it wasn’t long after that that we had our first fire in the wilderness, a little one that didn’t amount to much, which would have been the first fire with Chief of Forest Service sanction in the Nation.

DL: That was the Bad Luck Fire?

OD: No, the first one was a little one that burned up on a hillside. It was a lightning strike and it was only two and a half acres and it went out by itself. Then the second one was the Bad Luck Fire and that one is just rife with personal experiences and things that happened.

DL: Can you talk about a couple of those that seem very vivid to you?

OD: Sure, I’d be happy to. Oh, yah, there’s some real vivid memories there. I was in Missoula at a meeting when the Bad Luck Fire started and they called me, they called me on the phone, we got a fire, we got a fire. And I tell them I got to leave the meeting and go down to Hamilton and, of course, at that point whether to apply the prescription or not fell to our supervisor, I mean only the forest supervisor could make the decision. And I wasn’t about to make the decision sitting in a meeting so we went down and the group briefed me on where it was and so forth and whether it would fit in and we said yes and so we allowed it to start burning. And it burned for 42 days as I recall. It was a fascinating experience. Now, I mentioned that I had, how I got to the job, but I didn’t mention that I was, fire was, you know, and I say I don’t know where I got this idea of fire use, fire suppression and fire was something I had been doing. I was a fire, what they called the fire control staff at that time on the Challis National Forest for a couple of years.

DL: Uh-huh.

OD: And that’s, that’s in the Middle Fork country in what’s now the Frank Church Wilderness and so I had some feeling there but I was a fire person. I had started when I was in the Bridger National Forest as a person who, you know, went out as an assistant ranger when we fought fire and I wasn’t in what I call the fire fraternity but I was active in fire management and the leadership of the Forest Service was kind of pushing me towards that as part of my career interests. And so I knew that I wanted to make that decision based on the information and make it carefully but then when I got, so soon as it was going I didn’t go over there immediately but the first weekend that came along I took my two boys and we went over and we walked the fire, we could from Paradise you could walk the fire.

DL: What does it mean to walk the fire?

OD: Just get out and walk through it. And I was carrying a, I was carrying a shovel which every good fire fighter carries a shovel when they’re on the fire line and it was like, the personal recollection is really strong, standing on a hillside and there’s a burning log and my inclination is as a fire control person was to turn that log so it wouldn’t roll down the hill, you know, turn that log and then I thought no that’s not what we’re doing. It’s a paradigm change. I mean the agency, even though I had a commitment, there’s still the old habits. And the whole agency had that, the old habit. It was a slow transition. Even when it’s logical, even when your brain says this is what we’re doing, you know, habits and emotion carry and so it was like I’d want to stop those rolling pine cones from burning and rolling down the hill and I’d want to turn the log. And I had to resist my own impulses of suppression. And finally after about an hour and a half of walking through the fire with my sons we were, oh, I think probably around 10 and 8 at the time, they could keep up and the fire was burning benignly and you could see it creep along and then take out a little patch of Douglas fir and you say yah that’s one of the things that we wanted to do and blah, blah, blah. And so it was just a revelation to be out there. Everything up until then had been an intellectual game. At that point, I mean you’ve been on the fire and you really watched it and you begin to think of it in ecological terms, even though I was prepared for it but to set there, and so finally I would just set and watch it. And you could see how it was varying its pattern of burning and how intense it would be here, wouldn’t be over there, then this big conflagration. And see always before in the agency and even with me with my feelings for fire you always feared it. When you went on a fire you did not observe the fire, you put it out. I mean you were there to put that fire out and so you never stopped to really look at it, to really watch what it was doing. And now you might in a prescribed burn like I had seen but when it’s a wild fire it’s just like your head clicks and so the reality is I don’t think hardly any people in the Forest Service that were in the fire game had ever just sat and watched a fire burn very much. It just wasn’t what they were doing. And that’s why this little technician burning that I watched was so unusual because he was using it for a prescription and not very many people were really there, some but mostly they were using fire to burn slash and do those things. And he was using it in a, so it’s sort of like a bigger microcosm of the change the agency had to do. I had to do it.

DL: Did you realize at the time how much of an impact what you were doing would have on the, on fire policy for the whole country or is that something you realized looking back or a little bit remote?

OD: Looking back, you know, looking back because you, I don’t know, when you’re pioneering something you don’t really think in that way of well I’m making a difference in the country. What you really do is I want to do this because I think it’s right and you focus on that instead of the broad policy implications. I didn’t have enough maturity and, you know, when I was 50-60 I might have looked at it and said hey we’re changing the whole view but at the time no. And that’s a fascinating thing that you raise. It’s one of the things I’ve learned over my career is that if we are on the cutting edge you normally are not doing it to try to influence the whole world. You’re doing it to make that part of the world that you’re in whole. You’re trying to do the right thing as you see it and often, and it’s a fallacy of youth, you don’t understand what you’re setting in motion. Old hands sometimes will say oh, no, you start that and a lot of the old time fire guys were saying, nah this fire use is bad. It’ll teach people bad habits, we won’t put out fires, and there was a tremendous resistance within the fire community. Without Bud Moore’s leadership in the Regional Office I don’t think we could have ever gotten this done and on the Bad Luck Fire was typical. Now, the Bad Luck Fire there were some instances there I’d like to talk about but one of them, the major one was the fire got outside the fire management boundary and it’s a fact that has been well documented and so forth. And it crossed the river, the drainage, and started on the other side of the drainage. Well, by rights you’d put all the fire out but this is our first fire. It was our chance to do it and so I made an executive decision which was probably wouldn’t have stood the test of legality that were going to have two fires. We were going to have fire on the north, on the south side of the drainage which we were going to suppress and a fire on the north side which we were going to allow to continue to burn. And we really needed that fire on the north side. So it was sort of like cutting and fitting the situation. We’d never really thought about that in total depth so we called in the incident command team and that incident command team was just furious that we wouldn’t let them put the fire out. And I can’t remember that fellow’s name, it’ll come to me, but he was an old time fire fighter and he thought we were totally crazy and that we shouldn’t do that. Let me put that fire out. And, no, without Bud’s blessing I couldn’t have pulled it off. Even though I made the decision he supported it and later on the policy was that if it gets out of control the whole thing was out of control and you got to put it out or do something to it or we’ve got new terminology and new strategies, we’ve learned so much since then. When the fire was burning I just had to be out there. The other things went aside. And then after the fire within just I think it was five days after the fire had gone out by itself Bob Mutch and I went out and we walked the fire. And this fire became a very personal fire.

DL: The Bad Luck Fire?

OD: The Bad Luck Fire, the Bad Luck Fire. And it was beginning to sprout green, grass was coming up, little forbs popping up, and you saw it as something of renewal, not something of destruction. And it had burned in a nice mosaic. It had burned out some dense stands of Douglas fir, left all the, pretty much all the big pine, and it had done what we wanted. And when we watched it we’d go out there and for two or three days it wouldn’t even, it would just smolder and then you’d get the right conditions and you’d get a little bit of a burn for a day or two days and you could see the varying intensities of fire. And that’s one thing that it demonstrated that most of us had never seen because when you go out to suppress a fire it’s usually in a very active burning stage and all you see is pretty uniform black and a running fire but when you’ve got a fire burning under the natural conditions it creeps, it burns a little here, it doesn’t burn there, etc., etc. if it’s in the right conditions, if it’s under prescription. So it was very, Bob and I walked that and then we went back the next spring and by the next spring when the snow went off I mean it was a carpet of grand flowers and things coming back and you knew. And so the result of that for, I don’t know, maybe 10 or 15 years, I’d be on a speaking circuit talking about the value of wilderness fire. And by then we fully knew what it meant from a systems standpoint within a very short time. It was clear it was going to change the agency. And although we weren’t thinking as much about that at the beginning it became clear very quickly. And it was almost like a religious experience to experience that fire. It gives you a passion for it, when you’ve done that you’ve invested so much in the study, so much in convincing people to do it that it really does become almost an ideology.

title: Inspiration
introduction: In this episode, titled “Inspiration” we hear about some of the poems and stories written by Josh Dolezal, inspired by his time working on fire and trail crews in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness in the 1990s. Now an associate professor at Central College in Pella, Iowa, Josh was born near Libby, Montana. He likes to tell people he was “almost born in a teepee.” His parents raised him to be familiar with the outdoors and to appreciate his native Montana landscape. This, combined with his interest in creative nonfiction led him to write these pieces about his time spent in the wilderness.

Audio Clip

Interviewee: Josh Dolezal
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: October 7, 2011

DL: So, I’m really interested in the writing that you’ve done about the Selway-Bitterroot and I kind of put you in the same category as Norman McLain, you know, in terms of really capturing what that place is. So I’m going to get you to talk a little bit first about your essay “Selway by Headlamp” which was published in creative non-fiction.

JD: In Fourth Genre.

DL: Fourth Genre, right. And so do you want to talk about how that essay, maybe just talk about the content of it and then how that essay came about.

JD: That was the second essay that I wrote about the Selway. The other is called “The Sense Mill” and it came out in ISLE which is the journal for Interdisciplinary Studies of Literature and Environment. And “The Sense Mill” was about my first season hiking in to the Moose Creek cabin when I decided I was going to surprise the crew boss by hiking in in one day and he told us, you know, stay overnight at Three Links which is half way, 13 miles. And it was hot and we got up early and started hiking in the dark and we’re making good time. I just forgot to drink. I was in good condition but I just didn’t drink enough water and I got heat cramps and passed out actually at a certain point and so “The Sense Mill” is about, it wasn’t necessarily a near death experience but when you get to the point where you’re passing out and you’ve got full body cramps, I mean it could go either way essentially. You’ve extended your body far enough and so I was sort of meditating on the intensity of that experience, what I learned about, what I thought I learned about near death from that. And “Selway by Headlamp” sort of picked up with that theme because it was the next summer I hiked out to go to a conference and hiked out in one day and learned my lesson about how to hydrate. It was no problem really to hike the distance, it’s a fairly flat river trail, and so it wasn’t that hard, it was just a matter of drinking often enough and so I hiked out, flew to my conference, flew back, and in the airport on my way home I had talked to my sister, she was going through a divorce, I was distraught about this, and realized that I couldn’t probably sleep that night and I just decided to hike all the way in in the dark. And so, I don’t need to summarize the whole essay but it was a sort of braided narrative with, you know, concerns in the present and all of the milestones along the way to the trail giving me a sense of these were things that I had experienced in daylight and I was experiencing them in a new way in the darkness which was much like this experience my sister was going through in her divorce and ripples in the family and friends and all that. So in that sense I think the Selway gave me a chance to reflect on identity, on family, it was about more than just the wilderness experience. There was a lot, it was a touchstone for my life in other ways.

DL: And do you think the fact of walking, you know, one foot in front of the other on a river trail, is there something about the pace of walking a wilderness trail and the pace of thought. Do those things go together for you?

JD: I think walking is very meditative. I often fall into a kind of trance when I walk. There’s a different rhythm to that than running or cycling. For cycling you’ve got to pay attention to all kinds of things you don’t have to if you’re walking if you’re in good shape and you’re not out of breath or, you know, in pain or something. Walking is a fairly relaxing way of engaging with landscape and so, yah, I spent a lot of time thinking on the trail. I wrote, it was the second summer, so 2002, I spent most of the summer writing poems. I wrote apparently 120 poems and tried to distill them into a manuscript and so every day on the trail I was watching for things, for images that I wanted to share with others. I often had these thoughts of wanting to share what was happening with friends and because I was so remote for so long, for three months, I wrote lots of letters, you know, every 10 days I would get my stack of mail from the mule packer when he brought in the groceries so I was in touch with people that way but I felt fairly cut off from friends and because it was such a special experience I had a profound urge to share that and so poetry was one way I tried to do that. And often I was trying to reassemble kind of the raw material of what I was seeing so that it would culminate in a kind of, I don’t want to use the word epiphany necessarily, but I wanted there to be some kind of discovery in the poem, I wanted it to kind of detonate in the last line for the reader so that there was a sense of that intensity.

DL: So can you give an example or two?

JD: Well, one very short poem that I can quote that, it’s probably better read because it’s so short and harder to probably follow, it’s called “Geometric” and I can just explain the basic idea. I was thinking about the Pythagorean Theorem randomly one day and thinking about the idea of feeling connected to landscape. I think I was reading Mary Blew’s “Bone Deep in Landscape” at the time and so this idea of the human being connected to the earth and I was thinking of the human being the vertical leg of the triangle and the earth being the horizontal leg and the view or sight connecting the two. And so the poem is called “Geometric” and it goes “Glacial basin scraped clean of all but grass, scattered birds, view so plain it could be the square root of the sum of this body, this earth.” So I don’t know if that needs for the reader in quite the way that it did for me but I was trying to reassemble a thought process and a kind of connection and an image that would share that experience.

DL: So, are there a couple of places in that landscape from where you had that experience like maybe up at Wylies or where you had that experience of looking down and?

JD: Well, I wrote that poem I think on Freeman Peak, I didn’t write it on the peak but it was about that trail going out to, what is that lake, past Freeman Peak, I’ve forgotten. It’s not Horse Lake. I’d have to look at a map to remember the lake. I only went all the way out to the lake once because there was so much work to do in that trail. There was one time that we did a hitch part way and then came back but it was about the ridge line up there which was so spared and I was just thinking of, you know, the alpine country is so simplified in some ways, it was kind of like that square root idea.

DL: So you guys did that trail or was that just a trip that you did, did you clear that trail?

JD: Uh-huh.

DL: Okay.

JD: We did some erosion control and that, you know. I don’t think that was one of the brushy trails. The Big Rock trail was brushy and just difficult. We never fully got that one done. But we had several loops that we did. The one that we did probably the most often was up Grizzly Saddle, across Moose Ridge, and then down through Ditch Creek and back up. We went always up Bailey Mountain and sometimes we went different ways. We did a lot of brushing on Bailey Mountain the first summer. So sometimes we’d go up that way and then down past Isaac Lake and back to Moose Creek. I know another time we went up Moose Creek and camped at the trail junction and worked up towards Someday Johnson Creek because there’d been a serious burn there and lots of cedar had fallen and that was quite a job.

DL: So you were telling me about your poetry manuscript, that you were interested in addressing a different kind of wilderness experience. Can you talk about that?

JD: I think a lot of times wilderness is perceived as a sort of bourgeois concept, you kow, that it’s a place where people recreate, where people go to bliss out, and you know have these mountaintop experiences but as a seasonal worker had a very different view of it because I was, I enjoyed very much working, feeling that I was caring in some way, stewarding in some way the land and not just doing a frivolous, not that recreation’s always frivolous but it wasn’t just about escaping from things. I felt kind of connected to the history of the land in a more profound way perhaps. And also torn at times between, one of the reasons I wanted to do wilderness trails is I had completely lost faith in the fire suppression policy of the Forest Service because I realized we never fought to defend the trailer court, you know, we fought to defend trophy homes that had been built in places that they shouldn’t have been built. We fought to protect timber resource that was meant to be harvested. A lot of the fires we shouldn’t have suppressed, we should have allowed them to burn because they were, you know, meant to burn off some of the downfall, especially in the lodgepole stands. I remember walking through 10 foot deep jackpots of lodgepole blow down and, you know, when that burns it can sterilize the soil or seriously delays the regenerative process that fire should serve. So I was disillusioned with that and I suppose I thought of trail maintenance as a more straight forwardly ethical way of caring for the land but, you know, we were clearing trails for outfitters that were bringing in bear hunters and I felt torn about that. Sometimes I wished I could just let the trail die, you know, let the trail.

DL: Rewild itself.

JD: Overgrown.

DL: Yah, right.

JD: I have actually a poem about that. So this is a poem titled “Mean” and it was published in the Hudson Review. “Cutting brush along a mountain tail, he fights two willful extremes, one desperate to trim back the whole hillside, shearing the banks straight up to the peak, the other longing to let the trail die, overgrow, smoothing the crease in the gray mountains brown. How fragile the middle space where he clears a footpath for a time, this labor worth most to himself, each sweep of an arm purging dust from his blood and the hearth at his core, clean enough for a household of one.” This is another one called “June Dream”. It rained every June that I worked out there and so this is about some of that and recalls some of the work that I did on the fire crew. “Low 40s, overcast, and wet. Rain drums on the shingles of an old guard station as day breaks without dawn. The muted trumpet of sky and the crews hard leather heels thump the frets of the trail. At the end of the day I stoke the cast iron stove, propping my boots along the edge to dry, rubbing what mink oil and wax I can into the seams in the toes. We spread our mummy bags on old canvas cots and I closed the chimney vent as the gas lantern sputters out. In the dark I’m left with the smell of wood smoke, the hint of mold in our clothes, and the glow of my own heat deep in the bag. Tonight I dream of a caravan of green pickups winding home just before dawn. The longest shift of my first year in a crew. We were done burning logging units for the tree planters, prewetting the edges with two inch hose, then lighting strips across the hill with drip torches. A job for late spring when rain and snow temper the burn. I was driving a club cab, third truck from the rear, my eyes singed with fatigue. Three young men slept in the back seat draped over each other like jeans in a heap and my crew boss slumped against the door in the front, his face buried in a fleece. Hannah, the other rookie on the crew sat next to me, the red lights on the dash mirrored in her eyes. I could smell her skin lotion and the wood smoke. My gaze locked on the tail lights of the truck ahead as my palm crept down the shift to her knee. As we turned a snore from the back made me slip my hand high up on the wheel, cinching my grip. In my dream she nestles against my shoulder as we take on the shape of two ridge lines, the silhouettes of our heads like twin peaks beneath a knuckled moon.” And then I’ll just read one more. This is the title poem of the manuscript. And this was toward the end of the summer. I remember seeing Someday Johnson Creek which was at that time a fresh burn so I think it had burned the year previously or two years prior to our visit and I remember just walking through this moonscape on the top of the ridge and seeing this little ribbon of green that came down through the middle of that and it was a series of very gentle pools and you could just, you know, it wasn’t a hot spring but you could just sit in a pool and have a bath and it was kind of a heavenly spot to discover on a hot day. So this is “Someday Johnson Creek”. It starts with an epigraph from Hilda Raz from her book “What Is Good”. “I have had this lesson not to care for the bones. Late in a trail hitch, grown brown with sun, solid with miles of climbs, I drop my pack by an alpine stream, cresting the ridge to watch for the others. Free of weight my chest a wide house of sky. These 500 yards could be life after death, an unending sprint with no need of rest. But if bad luck lets me die in a house instead of on bear grass send the body to school, let them learn what they can, so long as they grind the remains and spread them on these craggy peaks where the flies do their work with the sun.”

title: First Trip In
introduction:
In this episode, titled “First Trip In” Mary Erickson talks about falling in love with a wilderness area she hardly knew existed.

Mary Erickson grew up on a farm in Wisconsin, but fell in love with the wilderness when she visited her brother at the University of Montana. A trip into the Selway-Bitterroot wilderness turned into seven years’ employment at Selway Lodge and North Star Ranch. Here, Mary talks about the first time she flew to Selway Lodge and the magical way that the wilderness captured her heart. Her love for the area even earned her the nickname “Selway Mary,” a moniker that still follows her to this day.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Mary Erickson
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: October 6, 2011

DL: So, Mary, what I want to ask you first is if you can tell me about your background, where you grew up, and just any details that might be relevant to your later experience in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness.

ME: Well, I grew up in Wisconsin on a, essentially a truck farm and went to school there and went to school in Wisconsin, a couple of different colleges. And I think part of my growing up years created the interest that I have in the wilderness area and the reason, it was the reason I jumped at the job when I got one because as kids growing up we had fun, on probably five miles of countryside around our farm on lake shore and woods and marsh land, and things of that sort. And mom, God bless her, most of the time didn’t know where we were if we weren’t doing our designated jobs but, you know, she just felt very confident that we were safe wherever we were. So I was used to being kind of independent.

DL: Right.

ME: In my exploration in nature so. And then I went to college in Wisconsin and my brother had come to the University of Montana to go to school, he transferred out here and I had to come visit him and once I got here I knew I couldn’t go home because it just was where I belonged and I was lucky enough to get, there was an ad in the paper for Selway Lodge. It didn’t say Selway Lodge, it said back country guest ranch looking for assistant cook. And I thought what the heck I can cook, been cooking for a family of nine. I’d done some commercial cooking, you know, what the heck. I’ll send them a resume and in those days you wrote a letter and you put it in the mail and then you waited, you know, two weeks or whatever to get it back. Well, I didn’t know that their mail was at that time going to Darby and they had flown out and picked it up. My girlfriend and I went to Glacier Park for four or five days and when I got back I had a note back from them, it was Pierces at Selway Lodge, that they were going to be interviewing me in Missoula the following week. I’d only planned to stay here like, well, two weeks but, you know, until the money ran out. And I called the phone number that they had left, they actually were out in town at the time and I spoke to Mr. Pierce on the phone and I said well how will I know you when I get to the airport for the interviews and he told me well you’ll be flying in in a little yellow and white plane and he always wore this red and white polka dot baseball cap, well, that won’t be hard to find. So we agreed upon a time to meet at the airport and I’m thinking wow, like, he has a plane where is this ranch. I didn’t really care though, you know, it was all adventure. And when I got to the airport the designated day I, the airport was a lot different than it is now. I went right to the windows and looked out over the tarmac and I just watched and I saw his little plane land and taxi in and I saw him get out and come walking in so I meet him at the door and introduced myself and we had a real great interview and when I walked out I, my brother had dropped me off and when he picked me up I said I got that job. I didn’t know yet but I said I got that job, I got to go get some hiking boots because it’s in the wilderness area.

DL: You didn’t know what?

ME: I’d never, well, I’d never, I mean yes it was constant, you have like pork and marsh and, you know, you have some mild country but not like out here.

DL: Uh-huh.

ME: And so I went and bought gear. I got a sleeping bag, you know, whatever I thought I needed and they called later in the day and said I had the job. And so two days later I flew into the Selway and that was the beginning of all of it.

DL: Wow. What year was that, Mary?

ME: ’71.

DL: And how old were you then?

ME: 21.

DL: Wow. So your very first introduction was, did you fly in on the air field at Selway Lodge.

ME: Oh, yes, I did.

DL: Yah.

ME: Oh, yes, I did. That was an adventure too.

DL: So tell us about your first kind of few days.

ME: I’d never been in a plane, any kind of plane, ever, to that point in time. Okay. He tells me has a, I saw the little plane, it, like, four people could sit in it. Okay. He’s going to pick me up in two days, meeting him at the airport, shoves my stuff in the back of the plane, get in the plane, he said, well it was a little rainy this morning so I wasn’t sure I was going to get out but I got out through a hole in the clouds and the weather’s is looking really good. So we head back in. I’ve never been in a plane before. I’m sitting up with the pilot and we flew down the Bitterroot. He picked me up here in Missoula and we flew down the Bitterroot and up over Lost Horse and down Bear Creek on the far side, which, of course, I didn’t know then. And as we were flying along first he lights up this little cigar. Okay, that’s not so good but then I was enthralled with seeing all this incredible country below me and all these little pocket lakes up in the mountain valleys and oh, my gosh, just incredible country until he started pointing out his emergency landing areas where his crashes are. See that little grove of aspens down there, if I ever have to put it down in this canyon that’s what I’m heading for. Okay, good, good, I’m relieved. We finally get down the canyon to the Selway River and we flew over the ranch and he tipped the wing so I could see the ranch house down below to let people there know that we were coming in to make sure horses weren’t on the air strip, something I would be doing a lot in my later days at Selway Lodge was clearing the air strip for planes. But, so we circled the strip and we went back to the mouth of Bear Creek and the plane turned around and as we’re coming down the river canyon there’s a mountain coming right at us, or we’re going at it, and so a ridge that comes down and Everett says it’s okay we’re going to pop over this. So we pop up over this little ridge and he sets it down hard in the end of the field and we’re zooming down the dirt runway which is just part of the pasture, no horses, zooming down the runway and we’re getting closer and closer to the house and there’s a rail fence along the house and all the family’s out to greet the plane and are all waving as we come in, they’re all waving to me and smiling, big hellos on their face, and we’re still going and as we go by the fence by the house their faces all changed to looks of abject horror and big Os for their mouths and I said to Everett is everything okay. He said ah, well, ah, the brakes aren’t working too good because the grass is wet. And there’s a mountain coming, right at the end of the airstrip is a mountain. Everett says we’re going to take the dog leg. Okay, and there’s a little beeper going beep, beep, beep, beep, beep. He said don’t worry about that. We didn’t hit the mountain. He kind of pulled the plane to the left and went around the edge of the mountain and there was another little piece of the meadow and that’s where we stopped the plane and turned around and taxied back down to the house. And everybody’s saying oh, thank God, nobody’s ever used the dog leg before. I was as happy to see them as they were to see me.

DL: How many people were in their family then?

ME: Well, at the lodge at that time there was Freddie and Everett and Tom and Melany and Fred and then there were a couple other staff members there. And it was our tradition that I learned, I mean whenever a plane was coming in you went to the fence and, you know, waited for them because usually you stopped just past the house by the little barn, not clear up around the edge of the mountain on the dog leg.

DL: Right. So your first, you know, you were just immediately immersed in this culture back here?

ME: Oh, yah.

DL: Yah. So what was that like?

ME: It was incredible. It was like I’d died and gone to heaven. You know, it was just, I mean it was such a beautiful place…

title: Wilderness Encounter
introduction: In this episode, titled, “Wilderness Encounter,” Sarah Swett and Bill Worf each recall an encounter that they had at Running Creek. In a short space of time, different philosophies met and collided, yet both people ultimately express their love of and respect for wilderness. Listen as the story is told during two different interviews of a Wilderness Encounter.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clips


Interviewee: Sarah Swett
Interviewer: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: Moscow, Idaho
Date: May 11, 2011

DL: Yah. Well, how would you answer that question what different people want from wilderness? You must have seen every different shape, size or desire back there for wilderness.

SS: Yah, and it was you saw all of it and I couldn’t, I don’t know. I mean, people would come by to me and say can I have some lemonade. Like they’re back for their wilderness experience but they’ve run out of lemonade. It’s like, well, drink water, you know. I have to bring all my stuff in here too. Why are you here, oh, river, the river people. It’s all about, I mean that’s a whole nuther thing this, you know, the obsession with the danger of the river and which I took a couple of little raft trips, I hitched rides. One of which I got out at Goat Creek. Two days later their raft had flipped and some horrible thing and everybody almost died. It was just awful but it was like God you idiots. What, what, why do you need to pit yourself against this perfectly nice piece of land that’s just doing its thing. You know, the river’s just running, just let it run. Why? But for some people it’s a challenge, it’s something they need to conquer, and for others it’s something that just can exist. For others it’s a place to live and it’s just where you happen to live. And certainly for me I just happened to have this series of events that plunked me there and I’m deeply fortunate about that but I, it wasn’t a, you know, it’s like being born in and living in Dixie. Yah, you know it’s like wow we’re going to go and live this. This is where my parents had their place and that’s where I grew up and we lived there and we worked in the bar. You know that’s what it is. And even though I didn’t grow up there it was just sort of a series of things that happened to me and I think more people tend to be like, oh, how nice and then they have an idea about it and I don’t understand that. Although one of my most conflicting, odd moments at Running Creek was mowing. You had to mow a lot because for fire and for snakes. Those were sort of the two things and how it was this whole aesthetic thing about the nice lawn. Dodie had had this fabulous lawn and it’s really important to maintain Dodie’s lawn. So I was, but I had a riding mower. So there I am with a riding mower wearing these little skimpy shorts and my braids 100 miles long, you know, driving around and the trail, the main river trail went right by my gate. You know, there’s this little fence and then there’s the main river trail and this guy came by and he sort of was watching me for a bit with these dark glasses. And so, you know, the mower didn’t start easily so I left it running and then went over and started to chat with him at the top of my lungs over the sound of the mower. And he was sort of asking about the place and it turned out it was Bill Worf who at that point was not yet blind. I guess he was going blind and it was one of his, his last trips into the Selway. And he had tried really hard to buy Running Creek because he was, very much wanted to buy all the private places and get rid of them and the Houghtons had outbid him because they could pay a million dollars or whatever it was they had paid and there was I running my damn lawn mower. I mean, it must have been such an awful thing for him. It’s like this is everything I didn’t want. And I’m having this chat with him. I don’t remember what we talked about or how I learned all that background but afterwards I just felt really small, you know, just. I mean, I was, it was my job. I was the caretaker. I didn’t own it or anything but at least I could have turned the damn mower off and, you know, made it be quiet so we could have a nice wilderness experience. But that was really peculiar that two completely opposite points of view about that wilderness meeting over that fence and he walked on his way and I climbed back on my mower and kept mowing. And there you have it, you know.

JH: That’s a great story.

DL: Thank you Sarah.

title: Defining Wilderness
introduction: In this episode, titled “Defining Wilderness,” Bill Worf, a tireless wilderness champion and lifelong conservationist, tells us in one of his last interviews about his passion for wilderness. Although Bill passed on December 21, 2011, his legacy will be remembered as long as wilderness survives in this country. He spent his long life working to establish and preserve wilderness as a special, set-aside place where people were not allowed to interfere with Mother Nature. Bill was born in 1926 in Reed Point, Montana, was raised on a ranch near Rosebud during the Great Depression, fought in World War II in Iwo Jima, and then obtained his Bachelor of Science in Forestry in 1950 in Missoula. When the 1964 Wilderness Act was passed, Bill was assigned to Washington DC to lead the wilderness program, and his influence and interpretation were the guiding forces behind the wilderness fire policy of allowing naturally-occurring wildfire to burn, as well as the strict one-launch-per-day river policy, and the use of primitive non-motorized tools by trail maintenance crews. After retiring from the Forest Service, Bill and his colleagues founded Wilderness Watch, a non-profit organization dedication to maintaining the Wilderness Act in its entirety. As Bill said, “I shall not perish from this earth without doing everything within my realm to save its most precious non-human resource.”

BM: Yah, I guess, Bill, I want to take not just you but all of us back like 41 years. And, you know, you do the math and that’s 1970 and you remember that I think as well as I do.

BW: Oh, yes.

BM: And it was the most monumental backpack trip I ever made in my life, Bill, because it was you and Orville and myself and Dave Aldrich.

BW: And Bud Moore.

BM: And Bud Moore. The five. And there we were up by Cooper’s Flat.

BW: Right.

BM: With our tents up and our campfire talking to answer Jamie’s question, what are we going to do, how do we get started, what’s first, I mean how do we bring everybody along, it’s something brand new. So now here in 2011 I’d be really interested as you look back over the last 41 years to what, what you thought on that camp that we had at Cooper’s Flat, Bill, where we were really envisioning the role fire should play in wilderness and then where we’ve come to over these intervening 41 years to today. In other words, contrast what you wanted to see happen then to where we are today.

BW: I don’t know.

DL: You don’t know.

BM: Too big a question.

BW: Yah.

DL: Where do you think, Bob? Bob, what do you think?

BM: Well, yah, before what I think, I mean what are your recollections of our campfire back there in the wilderness in ’70, Bill?

BW: Oh, well, you mean as far as.

BM: Yah, just the five of us together around the campfire.

BW: Well, we knew, I knew, you knew that we had to let mother nature play its role and that was our goal was to try to let that happen. And.

BM: Uh-huh.

DL: Did you guys have any disagreements?

BW: I know.

DL: You were all of one mind?

BW: Pretty much, yah, yah, pretty much of one mind.

BM: Well, through Wilderness Watch, Bill, in all these years and all your personal engagement after you retired do you think, you know, looking in from a Wilderness Watch perspective that the agency has kind of lived up to what your vision was back then?

BW: No.

BM: With fire?

BW: No.

BM: Uh-huh.

BW: No, I’m afraid that the agency has lost track of what their mission was.

BM: Uh-huh. In what way?

BW: Well, I think we, I think we wanted to make mother nature do our thing rather than, rather than us letting mother nature play its role.

BM: Uh-huh, uh-huh. Kind of just superimpose our values on her natural system.

BW: That’s right. Yah.

BM: Yah.

DL: It’s hard not to do.

BM: It is.

title: Smokejumping
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Smokejumping,” we hear from Dick Hulla, who not only worked as the first river ranger in the Selway-Bitterroot wilderness, but also jumped into fires in many places in the western United States, including the Selway-Bitterroot during the time when the “let-burn” policy first came into play.  

Dick grew up in Missoula, and applied to work in the Forest Service at the age in 18 in the late 1960’s, right after the passage of the Wilderness Act.  Throughout college at the University of Montana, Dick spent the summers working in the wilderness, where he met and impressed Emil Keck, who oversaw his work maintaining trails and bridges.  Dick went on to work as a river ranger, providing vital information to the Forest Service toward what was to become the unique “one-launch-per-day” rafting policy.  He later smoke jumped, and earned his pilot’s license, working as a backcountry pilot and firefighter throughout the 1970’s and 80’s.  Here, he tells us what is involved in smokejumping on a backcountry fire, and describes the practice of “herding” a wildfire that is to be allowed to burn.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Dick Hulla
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: April 15, 2011

DL: Could you walk me through what it’s like to do a smoke jump from, you know, a pilot and a smoke jumper’s point of view? Do you, you know, how do you prepare, where are you supposed to drop, you know, what equipment, what do you do when you hit the ground?

DH: Well, from the jumper part of it, I mean that’s the tip of the spear, you know. It’s a whole lot like a military action I think and people that have been in the military equate it to, you know, military type of operation. But you’re, by the time you’re jumping fires for the Forest Service you’re pretty well trained. The training is superb and they can take people, young men, who have never ever even been in an airplane let alone parachute jump before and within three weeks if you make it through the training you’re prepared. And so the training is quite good. The fire fighting, as far as the airplanes and parachute portion, the fire fighting portion they expect you to come in with that background already and that includes tool handling and chainsaws, you know, the tools of the trade. You’ve already have that.

DL: So when you, say, you get a phone call that says we want you to jump this fire and so is everything already packed for you or do you go pack your own stuff?

DH: No, you’re expected and most of the fires the usual pattern was that lightning, and most of our fires were lightning type fires, and so a lightning storm would happen late in the afternoon and so if you were in Grangeville, for example, you were close by and they’d, you oftentimes were flying right behind the storms or during the storms, you know, you’d be seeing ground strikes. Depending on the situation they could have somebody up just prioritizing fires at that time and just say okay we want you to go there, there, or there. A lot of times you were on a fire within an hour of the lightning strike. Other situations, yah, you might get a phone call and say we got a fire over in Wyoming and we’re going to leave Missoula at 4:30 and be over the fire just at first light.

DL: First light is like dawn?

DH: Yes, yah.

DL: Yah, I see.

DH: And you gotta have decent.

DL: You gotta see?

DH: You’ve got to be able to see. So, but, we, I remember, they don’t do this so much now but in those days, in the ‘70s and ‘80s, they, you know, you’d take off at 4:00 in the morning and have to circle over the fire for 15 or 20 minutes until it got light and that was a great strategy. I really like that because you’ve got, we have good air, jumping in the morning is way better than jumping in the afternoon just because of the.

DL: Why?

DH: The air currents. Afternoon you have wind, it’s a lot hotter, thermals, the air is less dense. Mornings great time to jump.

DL: And do you land in the, obviously you land in trees?

DH: Sometimes. You try to pick a spot near the fire that’s going to let you land on the ground and safely. If you do have to land in trees they try to pick tight grouped trees, reprod, reproduction. You’re not going to fall out of a tree and run into the side of a large 200 foot tall pine tree and not hang up.

DL: So, then, how do you get your parachute out of the trees?

DH: Well, there’s procedures for letting yourself out of the tree if you do hang up. It’s called a let down and you learn that in your training and then every year you go through a refresher where you redo all of the procedures. So the first thing is to get yourself down and out of the tree and you’re expected to be able to do that in a certain amount of time. It’s usually less than 10 minutes and you can safely repel out of the tree. You go and put out the fire and then you come back and get your chute. You either climb the tree if it’s a large tree that you can safely climb or if smaller trees you just cut them down and retrieve your chute or pull it out. But one way or the other you have to, the general practice is to climb the tree.

DL: So you have to be really physically fit?

DH: Yes.

DL: Have you ever encountered anyone who couldn’t actually do it who had to kind of say I can’t handle this physically?

DH: No, but there’s a lot of people who didn’t like climbing trees, who never were comfortable. I mean, everybody had to do it and one of the stations, the units is the ground school and they have an exit tower where you learn how to exit your plane. They have a landing simulator where you learn how to do your landing rolls. And they had tree climbing poles where you learned tree climbing techniques and there was always people that liked doing that or didn’t mind doing it and some people actually like it and I was one of the guys that kind of liked it.

DL: Uh-huh.

DH: I always liked being up and climbing and I was good at it. It was never a problem. And you could make a lot of beer by.

DL: Getting other people’s.

DH: By the people that didn’t like climbing you could get their chutes. A lot of people over the years, you know, you just had a reputation if you were one of the guys that liked to climb and get the cargo. I mean usually you were climbing for cargo more than you were for personnel chutes. After the jumpers are all on the ground safely they dropped the, at a low altitude, the plane comes in and drops the cargo boxes that have a parachute on them also. And they’re not steered, there’s nobody steering those chutes.

DL: Right, right.

DH: And it’s really dependent on the pilot’s skill because the pilot’s the one that’s positioning the plane and he also is the one that’s calling telling the people in the back when to throw their cargo out and so if you got a really good pilot who can get the cargo into a small spot then you don’t have to do as much climbing and that’s a good thing because you get to the fire quicker with your tools and it’s also you don’t have to spend the energy to go up and climb trees.

DL: When you were smoke jumping did you jump onto the Selway-Bitterroot very much or were you kind of all over?

DH: I was all over but I did make a number of jumps and most, I jumped right at Selway Lodge and the people who owned the lodge were back there with their clients and we jumped right in their airstrip.

DL: Was that Freddie and?

DH: Freddie and Everett Pierce who I knew quite well because I had worked for them in Aspen one winter. And I was in the back of the load. It was when I was still early in my career so I wasn’t squad overhead and it was during the 1974, the Independence Fire, which was a large, and this was again early on in that whole Bob Mutch’s program of letting fires run their course in the wilderness and that particular fire, they called it the Independence Fire because it started on July 4th, and by then the smoke jumpers were calling it the Moose Creek Black Hole because we kept getting sucked back there and for the smoke jumpers those fires presented all kinds of problems for us because there was never any clear direction, how they wanted them, all they wanted us to do was to herd them and you don’t herd wildfire.

DL: So what does that mean to herd them?

DH: Well, they said we don’t want it to go here, it’s okay if it goes out this direction, but we don’t want it to go that direction. And it’s, they talk about these safety issues and those fires were the situations that, you know, they talk about the 18 situations that shout watch out or the 18 standard fire fighter were all.

DL: Oh, okay. I see.

DH: And one of them should be herding wildfires because that’s definitely a situation that shouts watch out. You don’t have an anchor point. That’s the main problem. They tell you to, well we want you to start right here, you know.

DL: Yah.

DH: This particular fire had slopped over on the Bear Creek, it was about four miles up Bear Creek and it was burning on, it’s multi-thousand acres on one side and when it jumped across Bear Creek they didn’t want it to go, they wanted that controlled.

DL: But not the other side?

DH: But not the other side. Which is, Bear Creek was a pretty good anchor and so, yah, that was.

DL: So what’s an anchor, that’s just?

DH: Well, where you start digging, as you move around the fire you want to be anchored in to something that’s, so the fire doesn’t come back around behind you.

DL: I see.

DH: And so generally an anchor point is a river, a road, a rock slide, some kind of a natural spot that’s going to keep the fire from hooking around behind you. And that’s, I mean, you learn that early on in your fire fighting career that you don’t just generally, unless you can see your anchor spot and it’s a small enough fire, or see where you started but as soon as you lose sight of where you started you either have to have people back there watching that or you have to have a real good strong anchor point. A lot of those fires don’t have good anchor points, the management type.

DL: You mean the ones that are allowed to burn?

DH: Yes.

DL: Yah.

DH: Where they just tell you to go in and herd it.

DL: Do they still herd fires?

DH: They still have a, yah, that’s still going on.

DL: And is it to protect the inholdings and structures back there or just?

DH: A lot of different reasons but, yah, and there’s all kinds of, things have progressed, you know, I mean there’s a lot of policies and a lot of techniques, strategies that have evolved over the years to kind of mitigate that but it in my mind it’s still a problem. They haven’t solved it completely.

title: Crosscutting
introduction: In this episode, titled “Crosscutting,” we hear from Warren Miller, who took a special interest in using and promoting primitive tools for use in the backcountry, in particular the crosscut saw.  Because of his interest, Warren searched out experts to mentor him in the use and maintenance of crosscut saws, and eventually became one of the leading experts in the Forest Service on Crosscut saws, which led to his revising the manual produced by the Forest Service on the subject.  Here, he tells us something about the intricacies of sharpening saws by filing, he discusses brands of saws, and tells a story about a particular saw that received a name.

Audio Clip

Interviewee: Warren Miller
Interviewers: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: near Peck, Idaho
Date: May 6, 2011

DL: So you, when did you start getting an interest in crosscut saws?

WM: Well, actually about the first year I was there at Moose Creek I got interested in crosscuts. There, well, actually the first job I had was at Moose Creek was using crosscuts. A fellow by the name of Clem Pope and I ended up cutting out the old wagon road from Moose Creek up to the Ranches. I think that was the first task I had at Moose Creek using crosscuts. And then after that he, Clem and I ended up going down the Selway to Selway Falls and worked our way back up the river doing trail maintenance up to Moose Creek. This was before guard school and we had a saw with us and we did, of course, did some saw work then. And that spring, I think it was that same spring, and, of course, the, needed to have the saws sharpened and so one of the outfitters, I can’t remember his name, ended up doing, ended up filing the crosscuts for the district. I’d be sort of interested. I didn’t actually watch him but I was aware of the process that you got to sharpen these things to make them work. And I don’t know why, where I got interested in them but I just started getting curious about them and asked the people on the district what they knew about filing saws and again it was Clem Pope who knew more than about anybody else on the district but we’d go out in the saw shed and bang away on saws and things didn’t work out the way I thought they should and so I started pestering Emil Keck and says hey what do you know about this and he knew a little bit but not as much as, not enough to be able to answer the questions I had so he realized that both Clem and I were really interested in saws. And he ended up on one of his trips to the Coast looking up a filer by the name of Martin Winters who was a fellow who’d filed for logging camps starting in about 1927 and filed in logging camps for a good part of his life and at that time when Emil and Penny went to visit him was retired but was still filing for contest sawyers and Emil came back and said you got to go over there and meet this fellow because he knows what he’s talking about and so the next, well that winter actually Clem and I and Mary Ferguson went up to Olympia and spent a day with him while he graciously sharpened a saw while we were watching and answered questions. And he kind of put a bug in my ear about saws and filers and the whole aura of crosscuts and I spent the next two winters out on the Coast while I wasn’t working for Moose Creek looking for saws and saw filing tools and talking to as many filers as I could track down. And what started off, you know, as a hobby just kind of exploded or got out of hand or I’m not sure. It depends on your perspective. But the work season after I had visited Martin and gotten a little bit of a handle on how to file them I started filing saws for the district and filed for the district from then on, from then until I quit in ’91. But it didn’t really stop there because Bill Holman who’d been the ranger when I first got to Moose Creek had gone over to the regional office in Recreation and at the, not too long after he got there Missoula Equipment and Development Center had written a saw filing manual and Bill had gotten a hold of a couple of copies and send it in to me and Clem at Moose Creek and asked us to critique it after our introduction to them through Martin. And we realized that the manual was pretty deficient and told, well told Bill Holman that and that got back to MTDC or MEDC. It was then Missoula Equipment and Development Center. It’s now Missoula Technical Development Center. And so they invited me over to a meeting and I sat at a table with a whole bunch of engineers and told them what was wrong with their manual. And at the end of this about a four hour session there said well it looks like we need to rewrite this thing and I think you’re probably the one to rewrite it. How do you want to do this? So I eventually did end up writing a new filing manual. And that was distributed all over the country to Forest Service offices. I think each district office grabbed a couple of copies and regional offices got half a dozen or something like that.

DL: So what makes filing a crosscut saw so technical and so difficult?

WM: Um, well it’s, there’s a lot of different aspects that all have to work together. You’ve got several different kinds of, or you’ve got two different kinds of teeth and they each, each has to be sharpened up, or treated in a particular way so that they work with each other. A saw is not, a crosscut saw is not really a primitive tool because you’ve got, for it to work properly each of the teeth has to be filed essentially the same way in a very precise way so that it interacts most efficiently with the wood because unlike a power saw where you have a lot of power to muddle your way through a cut if the saws not sharpened properly your crosscut is human powered and humans don’t, well humans have a quarter of a horsepower at most that they can deal with and so you want a saw that, well you want a tool that is as efficient at cutting a log as you can make it. And so in order to do that you have to have the interaction between the two different types of teeth on a saw, how to explain it. I spend a week teaching people how to file saws and how to describe it in a couple minutes here. Basically it’s just a, it’s a very precise, it’s a precision tool made up of a number of different parts all of which have to be working in concert with each other for it to work efficiently and that’s basically what makes it complicated. It’s not, it’s not that each individual piece is very complex or difficult it’s just that they all have to be working together.

DL: And you now teach classes every year to young people, middle aged people that, how to.

WM: All ages.

DL: How to sharpen and how to use them? Or maybe.

WM: Not so much how to use them. But I’ve been, for the last 21 years I’ve been teaching classes over at Nine Mile Ranger Station at the Wild Lands Training Center over there and how to, well, how to select, how to take care of, how to resurrect and sharpen crosscut saws. That’s my primary, primary emphasis is actually on making them work. I’ve done a little bit of training on using them but mostly it’s how to make them work.

DL: And how many different kinds of saws are there, brands?

WM: Well, there are three primary, three main brands of saws. There was Simons, Disten, and Adkins were the primary companies but there were numerous smaller companies that made them. Well, there was a company by the name of Old Bishop. There was a number, there were a number of companies like, in fact, like Craftsman actually had a saw but I don’t think they manufactured their own. It was actually manufactured by Adkins and then they just rebranded it. But those were the primary, primary brands were Simons, Disten, and Adkins. And they quit making, Simons was the last one that made them. And there was a, actually a letter in the files at Moose Creek dated about 1967, I believe, from Simons Company to Moose Creek which was in response to an inquiry made by Moose Creek to Simons asking about saws in which it was stated that, I think it was 1967 or ’66 that their, was the last time they manufactured crosscuts. So any saws that we’re currently using are leftovers from that period and prior. And nobody at this point is making crosscuts that are worth a darn. There’s a company back in Seneca Falls, New York, that manufactures crosscuts but they’re a poor imitation of the older saws.

DL: Uh-huh. Wow.

WM: In workmanship and steel content and that kind of stuff.

DL: So do you see the crosscut saw as being an integral part to the spirit of wilderness because you have to deal with trees obviously in our wildernesses but you can’t use machines.

WM: Well, that becomes an interesting question and dilemma. Of course, what happens when crosscuts wear out, I mean, because we have, we’re working on a limited supply of crosscuts and they eventually wear out as you sharpen and use them. You know, there becomes a dilemma of okay what happens when you run out of saws. Is there a possibility of interesting, or having some manufacturer actually remanufacture them? Or do you just decide that the minimum tool no longer is a crosscut but it’s another type of tool, perhaps mechanized equipment? So how do you deal with that dilemma?

DL: So do quite a few saws have stories for you? That’s just really interesting that saws hold, you know, history and stories.

WM: Not very many. I mean, not that I know. Not really. All saws have stories but not, you know, I’m not aware of very many saws that have stories.

DL: Personal. Yah. Uh-huh.

WM: Or of specific saws. There was one saw that I do, that I filed every year. It was a nice little four and a half footer that I’d made out of a five and a half foot saw. I cut the ends off of it. And it happened to have been left some place in the weather and apparently a small maple leaf had fallen onto it. And it had been out in the weather and the maple leaf had kept the moisture and it had rusted the outline of that maple leaf right into the saw and it had been there long enough that it actually was etched right into the saw. It was a delightful little pattern and very distinct. And one of the trail crews latched a hold of that saw. A gal who made that her saw and she actually named that saw. So but every year when she came back to work she would ask for that particular saw which she could, of course, recognize by the maple leaf on it. That was one of my more favorite saws just because of the distinctive pattern on it. Pretty fun.

DL: Do a lot of saws have names?

WM: I don’t know. The, I guess a lot of the saws at the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation have gotten named. I’m sure a lot of saws have had, a lot of saws in the past have had names, not all of them complimentary. But I don’t know.

DL: Yah.

WM: I never named a saw. I called a saw names but I’ve never named a saw.

title: Managing Wilderness Is An Oxymoron
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Managing Wilderness Is An Oxymoron,” Warren Miller explains how the wilderness rangers helped to interpret the Wilderness Act in a practical, tangible way, by educating backcountry recreational users and promoting primitive tool use, among other things.

Warren Miller was born in Salt Lake City, lived there until he was eleven, and then his family moved to Phoenix, Arizona.  He attended Reed College in Portland where he majored in physics.  After graduating, and spending some time traveling in Europe, he and his brother took a work trip with the Sierra Club, which took them into the Selway-Bitterroot off of Elk Summit.  While on that trip, he was impressed with the country and its surroundings; he also met Dick Walker, who encouraged him to apply for a job as wilderness ranger.  In his words, “I figured well, I’ll try this for a year or for a season and I stayed there 20 years.”

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Warren Miller
Interviewers: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: near Peck, Idaho
Date: May 6, 2011

DL: So you went to, you went to be a wilderness ranger in 1971.

WM: Uh-huh.

DL: And you said you were there for 20 years. Did you change positions or were you in that position?

WM: I was wilderness ranger for 17 years.

DL: At Moose Creek?

WM: Well, I was working for the Moose Creek District but we, see the way the District was organized changed quite a bit after I’d been there a couple of years. When I first, when I started working at Moose Creek everything worked out of Moose Creek Ranger Station itself which is right in the middle of the Selway-Bitterroot. So it was, you know, the first couple of years was… When you’re at Moose Creek you’re at Moose Creek. There wasn’t, essentially there wasn’t outside. You were very much of a community and a lifestyle that really didn’t connect to the outside.

DL: Can you go into more detail about what that entails, the community and the lifestyle?

WM: Ah, well, it was like any community. I mean, you ended up helping each other, working with each other. You, if somebody needed… you ended up cooperating with other people. If you needed some supplies taken down, say, to Shearer you’d end up, you know, cooperating with somebody else who was going in that direction rather than making special trips. It was a sense of community, you know. Often during the four days off from our, you know, we’d work 10 fours, we’d have 10 days out in the field or 10 paid days or official paid days and then four days off during a two-week hitch. And the crews who did come back in to the station, often we’d end up having a barbecue or an ice cream feed or something like that on the porch of the ranger’s house. You know, Bill would have us come over and we’d end up, for the station people would have prior to that made ice cubes in the freezers in their refrigerators and so we’d have the old fashioned crank ice cream maker and we’d make ice cream on the ranger’s porch. And have hamburgers and that kind of stuff. It was just, it was a, in a lot of ways it was a very close community and developed the interactions and the relationships that small closed communities like that do end up developing.

DL: Yah.

JH: Good memories.

WM: And so I ended up going over to Lost Horse in 1973 to man that station and in a way it made a lot of sense because managing a wilderness is kind of an oxymoron. Wilderness by definition doesn’t need to be managed, wilderness manages itself. And what wilderness managers really are doing is managing people and mitigating the impacts of people on the wilderness resource. And so most of that is education. Some of it’s law enforcement for the recalcitrant people who refuse to be educated. So it makes sense to talk to people before they go in to the wilderness and try to encourage them to using the low impact camping methods and try to instill in them a little bit of sense of what wilderness is, although again that’s a subjective sort of thing. So it made sense to move the wilderness rangers to the external portals to contact the public. Which is, I think it’s good. It makes people a little bit more sensitive and aware to what wilderness is.

DL: Yah. So the Wilderness Act, I mean it’s specific in some ways, no roads, no machinery, but some of it’s the terminology is more vague and open to interpretation. Did you find yourself having to make rules or enforce things that, you know, that had to do with the word untrammeled or the word un– solitude that are more abstract?

WM: Well, the Wilderness Act is pretty general. There is room for enormous amounts of interpretation as you find just going from region to region. You know, you find vastly different ways of interpreting the Wilderness Act. Some, you know, regions for example take a lot more liberty with administrative privileges using power equipment or having administrative facilities than others so there’s enormous room for interpretation. And, of course, that very thing leads or lead or innumerable conversations amongst the, and discussions amongst the people working there. Well, what is wilderness? How should we do this? How should we do that? Well, what’s the moral? What’s the. I mean, just. It’s all very subjective.

DL: Yah.

WM: And, you know, what is wilderness character of a place. I mean, what is wilderness in the first place? How do you define wilderness? The Wilderness Act has certain definitions but, you know, it’s a lack of being a little bit, oh, what’s the word, vulgar. A good friend of mine says you know, the opinions are like assholes everybody’s got one kind of thing. And that’s the same thing in wilderness. You know, no two people are going to have the same opinion about how, what it is and how it should be managed and what should be there, what shouldn’t be there. Anywhere from Emil who said by golly anybody who comes in here ought to be just given a spear and a loincloth and let him deal on his own to other people who say you know you really ought to have a road up the Selway here so people can enjoy this place. I mean, it’s two extremes of opinion about the same thing.

DL: Yah.

WM: And one of the interesting things that I found, that I had to deal with or dealt with in terms of wilderness and wilderness philosophy is man’s place in wilderness and the kind of, there’s an overlying impression that man really isn’t part of wilderness and I think man’s very much a part of wilderness and it’s sort of. You know, I think that attitude of man being a part from wilderness is kind of a byproduct of the Judeo-Christian attitude that man has dominion over everything else when in reality man is part of everything else. I mean, he’s just an organism just like anything else is and that took me a while to figure out how to, how that works in wilderness that. You know, we are a part of this planet and we do have a part in wilderness and we are not a part of wilderness or a part from wilderness I should say. And that was kind of an interesting realization that, you know, we are, we do belong here but we also need to take care of the place and make sure that we don’t make a mess out of it which, of course, is true of the planet in general but…

title: Backcountry Bridge Building
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Backcountry Bridge Building,” Penny Keck tells us stories of the years in which she and her husband Emil worked for the Forest Service, building and maintaining bridges throughout what is now the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness.  

Penny grew up on a farm near Portland, Oregon. While in college, she applied for and obtained a job as a fire lookout in the Moose Creek Ranger District in the summer of 1967. Her boss there was Emil Keck, whom she later married.  During the summers, Emil and Penny trained fire and trail crews, manned lookouts and assisted the Forest Rangers with equipment and other work. But during the off-season winters, they built or replaced many of the bridges that span creeks and rivers in the backcountry.  Without the use of heavy equipment or large crews, Penny and Emil Keck together built many of the astounding suspension bridges that lead hikers and hunters deep into the heart of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness.
