orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Penny Keck
Interviewers: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: Kooskia, Idaho
Date: May 5, 2011

P: And then in the winter because there was no traffic around most of the time we constructed the various bridges that were collapsing on various streams. Occasionally we were at the Moose Creek Station where we put base logs in under a building or built, repaired some of the buildings there that were major repairs but the majority of the time we were out in a tent somewhere constructing a bridge.

D: So could, well like I’ve been back there many times and walked across those bridges but I and other people I’ve been back there with always wonder how you guys did it. Can you walk me through a bridge building, you know, what does one do if one wants to build a bridge in the wilderness or repair a bridge?

P: One of the things, are talking first off girder span or a cable suspension?

D: I don’t know the difference. Maybe you can explain that too.

P: Okay. Some of them didn’t require your extensive, they weren’t that long and requiring cables. They were called girder spans, anything from about 45 feet or less. That’s an approximation.

D: Uh-huh.

P: And then what you do is, of course, is haul all your gear. Well, the first thing is you’d hopefully the gods to be would give you a few dollars to do this project. And then after that was accomplished and I’m sure the rangers did a lot of the paperwork.

J: You guys would have to estimate the material though, right?

P: Oh, yes, everything.

J: I mean all the nails and cables and boards.

P: Once I was actually the leader instead of Emil. I turned in the projects myself with estimates and everything. Of course, with his awareness too and cooperation and tremendous knowledge. So and I but I don’t know if Emil did a lot of that or not. I have a strong suspicion that he just told the ranger and that was it. I don’t honestly, can’t identify that but once that was occurring and the dollars came down we would then try to pack everything to the site in late fall.

D: With mules?

P: With mules, horses. And have everything there and then we’d begin. If it was a girder span that was built with native material and you’d begin falling the trees and getting them to the site. If we could we could, we tried to fall those trees ahead of time. We learned after the first bridge to fall them ahead of time, let them season with wood preservative on them so it’d absorb in them and do it. And the cable suspension bridges we actually definitely did that and let them season and because a major failing for most bridges would fail in about 15 to 20 years we found out historically so every time you’d build a bridge you would tear the old one apart and find out where the weak areas were, why did this occur, how can I make an improvement so this will not occur as rapidly in the future. So it was never a just tear apart and proceed to build. You always tried to improve something, one way or the other. And, for instance, on the cable suspension they had this little tiny plate up there where all of this weight of the bridge came over the cap on the tower.

D: Okay.

P: Well, chose to get a big plate to distribute it then the water was still a problem. We put tar around it, etc. to reduce the water leakage into the bolted areas and the rebar areas but you still couldn’t prevent everything because actually I found out later tar is good only for two to three, four years and you need to, because it bubbles and then air and water will get through it. And so you needed to redo this constantly which was interesting. So I came up and suggested to Emil that we put a little cap over it, a little, and we did try that on the Three Links one. Now I understand that a lot of people voiced the idea that this wasn’t part of wilderness. It looked ugly. And it’s true. The bridge looks ugly, excuse me. I’m sorry but it does. Yuck. But anyway. And so we would proceed to get everything out, I mean, on the cable suspensions they were fascinating because you had to have gin poles up and even on the others gin poles up but the cable suspension took a little more effort.

D: So how would you get them up there? Would you climb up there or to get the cables up or?

P: Well, first you let the, lifted the gin pole up and then you’d have the guy lines on it. You’d lift it so it’d just be a little tipped, a little slant about five degrees or a little bit over the bridge because you wanted that a little bit over there because to lift that entire bridge up with that gin pole you needed to have it, there’s different methods this day and age. We put it on the main cable which was usually an inch and a half, inch and three-quarter inch cable and proceeded to lift this off the tower, the cap and post and batter assembly which is termed a tower. And then you could take the old tower off and bring, replace it with a new which was an interesting and you get all this rigging up there. Yah, you had to climb the gin pole and put it up there.

D: So it was just the two of you would do the whole thing?

P: Yes.

D: So that in itself would take a lot of communication between you and Emil?

P: Yes. And it was, you know, depending on the size of the bridge, sometimes it took us four months, sometimes it took us the Three Links which is 210 feet between towers plus approaches took us two years because we only did it in the winter so it was two winters. And so it.

D: So which bridges. I know you worked on Dog Creek, right, and Three Links, and which other bridges did you guys work on back there that you recall?

P: Gold Creek, Bear Creek, Ditch Creek, Dog Creek, Halfway, Meeker. We worked…

J: Cub?

P: Pardon?

J: Cub?

P: Yah, Cub. I can’t.

D: Well, that’s amazing right there.

P: I can’t recall all of them.

D: And how many years did you guys do this, how many winters?

P: As I said I was back at Moose Creek for I believe 21 years and of those years and of the… we probably were on bridges over half the time in the winter. Again because we were able to obtain some mechanized authority to use certain mechanized equipment at times.

D: Uh-huh.

P: Because on one rail on the cable suspension you had over 1,000 bolts on one. There’s two rails. Hello there that’d take you an arm and a leg of a lifetime to do. And so some things were just to drill through 12 inches of wood with a hand is would have been entertaining. Would have been. But, you know, there are, the Forest Service at that time was semi-practical in the authorization of that which was beneficial. But because of that you respected the public and therefore you chose to do this when the public would not be interfering with you or you interfering which is primarily the reason with the public.

D: Right. The solitude thing?

P: Yes.

D: So, okay, so you were out there all winter and so we’re interested in number one how did the snow and the ice interfere with the bridge builder or maybe even help with it and also did you ever see anyone, like how long would it be that you two, it was just you two for the, you know, the duration?

P: Most of the time it was us two for the duration. But at times there was somebody would come. It was a rarity but I believe only twice did we have people come. And winters were interesting in that they slowed you up at times but it also made you respect certain things as well. For instance, on the Goat Creek bridge the temperature was 29 below and therefore it was a little crispy crittered and because Emil didn’t like to hew I did all the hewing on the base timbers. And you couldn’t lay out and hew, layout required no gloves, you’d only spend about an hour and then you’d have to go into the tent for about five minutes to warm up. Then you’d go back out in that cold temperature. The other thing you had to do is before darkness set in you had to pick up every item otherwise by the next morning you may not find it for several months. Minor glitches but and it may be something you really needed because what you did is not only transport the hardware and stuff for the bridges in you also had to transport your food and items in as well. And actually we surprisingly people wouldn’t grasp that we had fresh, some fresh food on the bridges because what we did is dig a hole, line it with the boughs, and then put our apples, oranges, and grapefruit, cabbage, carrots, onions in there. They kept the longest, various foods, and then you’d remove them as you needed them and you’d cover it up with a just a, on top, a little sheet of plastic and then more boughs and then dirt over it. And it kept it for all winter. It was cool.

D: It wouldn’t freeze?

P: No. And if you’ve ever tasted frozen grapefruit tell me you know it kiddos. Biggie. That’s pucker city.

D: So were you guys ever tempted to go out for a, just to go out of the woods for a while and have a, you know, a meal at the Wilderness Inn or anything?

P: Actually no. Once in a while we’d go out to visit my folks at Christmas but it wasn’t something that you looked forward to. As a matter of fact, it was, I never looked forward to it at all. It amazed me to be able to flick on a switch and have lights, don’t misunderstand me, but or even when we got back to Moose Creek we had a real pillow. You know, in the winter camps it was our stupid jackets that served as pillows, not a pillow. I mean, and so you realized how fortunate you were to be able to live in a time like this in which you did not have all these amenities.

title: What is the Greatest Threat to Wilderness?
introduction: This is a special episode, titled “What is the Greatest Threat to Wilderness?” Debbie Lee, our project coordinator, asked many of the oral history interviewees this question, and she received some surprising and enlightening answers. Among the interviewees in this podcast are Penny Keck, a longtime resident of the Selway-Bitterroot area who managed equipment for the Forest Service, as well as worked with her husband Emil to build and maintain many of the bridges and buildings. We hear from Ed Bloedel, who helped write the first wilderness management plans, Eric Melson and Rob Mason who currently work for the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation, and Warren Miller and Bruce Farling, who worked as Forest Rangers in the Moose Creek district in the 1970’s and 1980’s after the passage of the 1964 Wilderness Act. From these varying perspectives, we hear about the possible future of wilderness areas and their importance in the lives of current and future generations. Slideshow: Scenic landscapes from the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness at various points during the past century, show how little the protected landscape has changed. In this place, it is possible to view wild land as it once was, and to enjoy the tranquility of recreation in a pristine area.

orginal_transcript:
AUDIO CLIP

Ed Bloedel

DL: So, what do you think is the biggest threat to wilderness, right now, at this point in time?

EB: Well, it’s… I’m a little big conflicted. Because of my experience of working with wilderness; I still work on these issues; I worked with the Central Idaho Wilderness Act down here. Politics, I guess. As congressmen, writing into the bills, though, that this is what wilderness is about. You should be able to use motorized use. You should be able to go in and do… dig with the diggers. Build up big water tanks for grouse and birds to be able to feed, for bighorn sheep in Arizona, the bighorns have to have water, or they won’t survive. Well, how did they survive for hundreds of thousands of years before we came along and said… and made it a wilderness, you know? And we got to dig these big water tanks, and we have to bring diggers in there to do it. Those attacks are coming from politician, and they’re coming from some weakness within our own agency, to say no. And that’s me… I don’t like to say that, because I love the forest service. I loved my job; it was the best job in the world. But, we’re making some decisions… We met the enemy, and it is us. But it’s not coming just from us, it’s coming from politics. Political pressure from motorized users that want more. From dam people that own dams that want the convenience of using the power tools and so forth. And the cheapness. The expense. So, those are the biggest threats. That, plus air pollution, which we haven’t got any… no real handle on at all, yet, for a lot of wildernesses in our country. Not these. Not the Selway-Bitterroot, yet, although some acid rain probably has fallen on it, but all around our country, beautiful wildernesses that are near coal-fire plants or other places that throw out acid rain, we still have some serious problems there. But to me, the biggest threat is still people that come up and want their own way with wilderness. If they’re a politician, or if they’re inside the agency, or if they’re outside. If they’re motorized users that want their own way, that want what they want, instead of looking at the act, and saying here’s the resource of wilderness, a place where we can look at that used to be this way, and say what have we done outside… how much have we changed the world? I can go in there and see that the world hasn’t changed. I haven’t changed. Here’s what I am. I have to depend on myself to protect myself from a bear or whatever it is that’s out there. I have to keep… make shelter. I have to keep warm. We lose all that if we don’t maintain that. So, the biggest threat is these people that want something for their own use. Or want the comfort and convenience of doing it that way. We get it from sheriffs, that, by gosh, we got to run in there to rescue people all the time. We should have some radio towers, some cell towers, so we can… We don’t need that. We’ve got to have some places where we’ve left civilization behind. That’s what wilderness is all about.

Penny Keck

DL: So what do you think the biggest threat to wilderness is then?

PK: Whew. That’s an interesting question and I don’t know if I have the background, capability, knowledge to appropriately address that. I can give you off beat responses but would they be. I’d have to think about that for a while because of the fact that the threat to a wilderness. I think it’s exterior, not interior, I know that. But what? Is it political because it can be removed with politics. And, or is it the overall lifestyle of the earth. In other words, the earth is reaching its carrying capacity. It’s influencing the wilderness whether it’s through acid rain, through a lot of other items being slowly carried, transported somehow into the, I don’t know. But it’s evolving and changing as we speak whether we, nothing is static. But we are moving it more rapidly to a state that it probably wouldn’t move toward. The biggest threat, I don’t think there’s no one biggest threat. I think there’s several and it’ll be interesting to see in the future what that shall be.

Bruce Farling

DL: Okay, and what do you think the biggest threat to wilderness is? Right now?

BF: Well, the whole array of human influences, obviously. And in that array… The thing about the concept of wilderness, it’s a human construct, really. There’s this thing out there; we call it wilderness, and this is the values we put on it. But the value that is pretty meaningful is the whole idea is to have, sort of, nature function without human… or as minimal human influence as possible. Now, we’ve been able to… you can do a pretty good job of that when it’s dealing with individuals going in there, you know, stay on this trail over here, don’t trash… you can deal with that. You can minimize… but we now have these global influences that are really… that we’ve caused that are really huge. Climate change is huge. So, I think that is… and the other sort of… it’s not quite global, well, it is a global problem, but invasive species. We’re moving stuff into these places, that sort of naturally functioning ecosystem doesn’t function naturally when all of a sudden you’re air-dropping these species that evolved from somewhere else in there, you know. And obviously, we’ve got issues with weeds, and stuff like that, but there’s aquatic invasive species we’re really worried about showing up in places. I don’t even think we’ve begun to conceive some of the stuff that could show up in a place like the Selway-Bitterroot that would be a problem.

Eric Melson

DL: Okay, I just have one more question. What do you think the biggest threat to wilderness is?

EM: The biggest threat to wilderness is, in my opinion, the lack of the younger generations’ use and appreciation. I think that that would be number one on my list, and the whole concept of wilderness slowly being forgotten about. It seems like in the 60s and 70s, with the environmental movement and all of that, there was this steam, the ball was rolling; it was a snowball effect, like it just got bigger and bigger and bigger, and people got behind it. The whole idea of wilderness, I think is the greatest idea that America’s ever had. To set aside land solely on the purpose of setting aside land for its values, and saving it for future generations, so that an ever-encroaching population can use it, not use it, but can enjoy it. I think that with the influx in technology, and with iPhones and video games, and wanting it now, and just with technology in society, and the way that we are moving towards this fast-paced ever-evolving culture that it’s going to get forgotten about. People are going to say, why did we do that again? Like, what’s the point of all this again? You know, when they’re all so busy with their iPhones and their Internet chat, and they have to update on their blog, and they have to Tweet things… that they won’t realize what they have in their backyard. That, I think, is my main… is the single greatest threat, is that it’s going to get forgotten about, and that ball is going to slowly slow down and the momentum of the idea, and the culture behind wilderness… The leaders that we’ve had, the champions that created wilderness, and fought for it, and realized that it’s now or never, you know, we can save these areas now, or they can go on cutting these areas. They can go on extracting these areas. They can go on abusing these areas. I think that positive experiences in wilderness are the only thing, the only way that it’s going to happen, and getting kids engaged in their natural areas around their homes, you know, the creek behind their house, building forts, snowball fights. Little things like that. Getting kids outside. That’s the single greatest thing, is kids now are more focused on getting home, and getting the next level on their video game than they are about going in riding their bike, and jumping off of something, and breaking their arm, and you know? What happened to the playgrounds with pea gravel where’d you get scrapes, and you have rocks embedded in your shoulder. It’s become easier now; there’s foam mats because parents get mad, because the kids came home with scraped knees and it’s the school’s fault because they have pea gravel. And, like, we as a society have gotten soft. We really have, and wilderness will never get soft. It’s always hard. It’s always going to be difficult, and we need that. We have to have that because it’s where we came from, and it gives us a chance to go back to that. It gives us a chance to go back to a landscape that was never touched, and never will be touched, and technology doesn’t belong there. Mechanized, mechanical things don’t belong there. It’s human power, and it’s going to be hard, and we need it, and I think that technology, and the combination of the lack of interest from younger generations are the single greatest thing that are compromising wilderness right now, in my opinion.

Rob Mason

DL: So what do you feel is the biggest threat to wilderness? Maybe not just the Selways but to Wilderness in general?

RM: Well, you could talk about short-term and long-term threats. The long-term threat, I know Eric and I talked about this. I would totally agree with what he said. Unquestionably the biggest long-term threat is awareness in the American public of what wilderness is and why it’s important. Without that awareness, it puts into question the ability to have political support for wilderness, and while we like to think of wilderness as this place that’s protected and whatever, and the reality is that it’s not. Politics made the protection of the Selway possible, and continue to make it possible, but some day, if the support isn’t there politically to protect these areas, they could just as easily get turned back into a non-wilderness area. So I would definitely say the biggest threat is the awareness in the American public about the value of protecting places, as wilderness. As untrammeled areas. I wouldn’t even say it has to be wilderness. Just protecting places in general for qualities that are important to an ecosystem. That allow humans and other things to thrive. That provide those benefits. Clean water, clean air, seed beds of genetic diversity, which is hugely important to the world, and certainly to humans. So there’s other short-term threats. The biggest short-term threat in the Selway is unquestionably weeds. Invasive weeds. Of course you can get into the argument of what’s… are invasive weeds natural or not natural, and that is an important argument to have, but if you just take the premise that invasive weeds aren’t natural, then that’s a huge threat that’s incredibly hard to control. It definitely is changing the character of the wilderness and will continue to, in terms of hydrology, in terms of vegetation, in terms of habitat for species, and therefore species themselves. I guess that’s what I would say is the biggest threats to wilderness.

Warren Miller

DL: Well, Warren, what do you think is the biggest threat to wilderness?

WM: Uhm. Huh. Well, the first thing that comes to mind is apathy. And a, the lack or the change of demographics for the lack of anything else from a rural to an urban environment where. I think a large percentage of the population is so out of contact with the world that supports them that they don’t have any vestment in the world that supports them and consequently there is not a sense of need to support that. So that in order to maintain a resource which wilderness is I think you have to have support for it because there are lots of forces that are interested in extracting resources from wilderness and unless you have a counterbalance to that the, you know, the extractive forces will prevail. And just the fact that wilderness has been legislated by Congress means that it can be unlegislated if there’s enough interest and pressure to do that. So that’s, I think that’s one of the biggest concerns that I have is that there’s not, the biggest threat is a lack of support base or a diminishing support base is I think what most concerns me. I mean, there are the things which, of course, will modify wilderness, things like global warming and that, but I, that’s not a, to me that’s not a threat in the same sense that dewilderness, what’s the word I want to use.

DL: Declassifying.

WM: Declassifying wilderness, thanks, is and the resulting mayhem that that can result in.

DL: Yah.

WM: Yah, that’s, I mean, I suspect that in the environment that we have now that you probably would not be able to create wilderness because there’s just not the support for it, or create wilderness in the same way that it was done, you know, prior to 1964.

title: Domesticity
introduction: In this episode, titled “Domesticity,” we hear from Sarah Swett, with stories about her first backcountry employers, Punk and Carolyn Wolfenbarger, owners of the North Star ranch. For several years, Sarah lived and worked on outfitter ranches in the heart of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, and knew many of the long-time residents of the area. Originally from Brooklyn, she fell in love with the West, the wilderness and with the fibers and textiles that she has used to tell her stories. Although life on a wilderness ranch involved long hours of work, cooking, caring for livestock, making hay, fixing fence or repairing buildings, Sarah used to get up at 4:00 am to knit and weave and spin, creating stories in pictures much like the stories told up and down the river in the backcountry. For more of Sarah’s work, visit her web page.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip


Interviewee: Sarah Swett
Interviewer: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: Moscow, Idaho
Date: May 11, 2011

DL: This was at North Star.

SS: That was at North Star.

DL: Okay.

SS: So that was the first.

DL: And what year was this?

SS: That was, well, that was 1979 that we first went in so it was the spring of 1980, it was May. Came out to Peck actually and literally took my stuff out of the vehicle we were in, it was Ian’s vehicle, and put it in Five Eight Dog, Dick’s then airplane, and Dick took me in and dropped me off– bye. There I was with Punk for my new job. And ended up not leaving the Selway, not leaving that even immediate area, for nine months. So that was my first chunk and it was the first, it was a very, to me it made perfect sense. It was very domestic. Instantly we had to be pruning the raspberries and digging up the garden and mowing and cooking and I learned what Punk liked for breakfast and I learned what Punk liked, the kind of cookies he liked at 10:00 in the morning to go with his cup of coffee. And Carolyn came in shortly thereafter. I think she was concerned at the time that I was in there by myself and that Punk wouldn’t show me how to run stuff properly so she who had been in the midst of chemo, I mean I was 19 and she was 70, she came in and started teaching me stuff. And half of my job it later turned out, half of my job was helping just doing physical labor, gardening, cooking, haying, all that stuff. The other half was being Carolyn’s companion and doing all the stuff Carolyn would normally have done which again at that end of the Selway for people who lived in there year-round, full time was a lot of gardening, a lot of canning, a lot of berry picking, wine making. I believe we made 116 gallons of wine which we made in garbage cans, 20 gallon garbage cans, mostly whatever was around, service berries, chokecherry, elderberry.

JH: Not rhubarb?

SS: They did not have enough rhubarb. We made raspberry sometimes if there was enough raspberries but the idea for them was that Carolyn was a very social person and people came by and they expected, they’d been coming for years, they lived in there for 30 years so, year-round. They had people stopping by all the time, Forest Service teams, everyone and they were hospitable. So if someone comes by you offer them a drink. But who’s going to be packing in beer. You can’t pack in beer. So you make wine. You can pack in sugar. Sugar is much easier to pack in and you certainly weren’t going to pack in anything that you couldn’t pick there. So the idea was to use the stuff that grew wild. So a lot of our time or my time, not Carolyn’s so much then, was spent picking berries which was a long and honorable tradition. I learned much Doty, George and Doty who had lived at Running Creek until a few years before and Doty used to wear, I guess, these huge high snake boots because she was terrified of rattlesnakes which, of course, were very prevalent there and on the lawn and sometimes meandering into the house and such. So that you do watch out. But if you have to pick four gallons of berries for every barrel of wine, it’s a lot of time outside in the brush picking berries.

DL: So you spent a lot of time with Carolyn. How would you describe her? I don’t think we’ve talked to anyone who knew her that intimately.

SS: Well, I mean, the first thing is wonderful. She was wonderful. She… brusque, extremely brusque at times. But also extremely kind and interesting and very interested. She had a… I think some things were hard for me because something that she, she loved and valued education. She’s grown up in Darby and had been able to go to the University of Montana for one year and then had not been able to afford to continue to go. Ended up working in Cutbank running a bar and eventually ran her own bar in Darby and that’s where she met Punk and had her own house and had a, you know, had made a life for herself and ended up then marrying Punk and moving into the Selway. But she never was able to go back to college and because I had left Harvard of all places she really felt that I should go back and that it was kind of a waste although she tried not to say that because at the same time she needed to, like it’s, you know, people are okay who don’t but don’t throw away that education which I was all about throwing it away. I was like, but Carolyn I’m so much more interested in what you know than in what they know. So she wrote poetry. She recited poetry. She read endlessly. We talked a lot about books. She would give me books. They read a lot of Reader’s Digest Condensed Books which I had never seen in my life before but became a great consumer of. After nine months I’d read pretty much everything there which was great, very peaceful. She and Punk and I in the evenings after a hard day’s work we would read and then we would talk about them. A couple of my favorite Carolyn stories, one had to do with cooking and because I love to cook and I thought I was a pretty good cook and I learned to cook on a wood stove and she really educated me on how, you know, you need this kind of wood and this shape wood for this, you know, for making bread versus making this versus making that versus cooking the hotcakes that you make every single day, hotcakes cooked on top of the stove, mix up the sourdough the night before. All, it was very, very ritualized, very steady which suits me down to the ground because I love routine and I love, you know, to know things but then I got in trouble for some things like the first time, well, probably the third time I cooked green beans when we had them in the garden and Carolyn said oh you fixed them this way again. Well, uhm, yes, I had lightly steamed them with a little butter and salt and pepper. And I had learned at that point to say well, Carolyn, and I said what’s wrong with them. And she said they’re inedible. Oh, okay, so how would you fix them Carolyn. Nope, you cut them into small pieces and you cut up some bacon and you cook them with onion and bacon for at least 20 minutes until they’re tender. You can digest them. Okay, so from then on that was it for steamed green beans. And interestingly by the end of the nine months of living there I had so adopted her ways of cooking that when I was with some other friends they’re like Sarah you’re peeling the potatoes, why are you, you never used to peel potatoes. Well, right, you don’t actually have to any more.

title: To The Next Generation
introduction:
In this episode, titled “To The Next Generation,” we hear from Bob Mutch, who passed on his love for the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness to his daughter, Linda, and reminisces about the time they spent together in the backcountry. 

Bob’s areas of special interest include forest fuel management, fire ecology, fire behavior prediction, wildland fire training, public and firefighter safety, wildland fire suppression, prescribed fire in wilderness management, fire safe strategies for the interface, and international assistance. Since 1994, he has served as a fire management consultant in Brazil, Bulgaria, Ethiopia, India, Italy, and Mongolia for the United Nations and the World Bank, as well as domestic projects in the United States.

After her years of accompanying her father into the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, Linda went on to do her Master’s degree at the University of Arizona Tree-Ring Lab in a fire-related tree ring study on giant Sequoia trees, and has continued the work her father began studying wilderness fire behavior and management.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip


Interviewee: Bob Mutch
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: April 14, 2011

DL: Bob, can you tell me when you first… like what was your very first experience in the land that’s the Selway-Bitterroot that you can remember?

BM: That’s pretty easy, because it’s such a memorable moment for me, I guess. It goes all the way back to 1970, and although I knew there was a Selway-Bitterroot over the mountains from Missoula, and I smokejumped in Missoula in ’54 and ‘5. I guess I’m going to have to take that back, because on my very first fire jump, come to think of it, right now, sitting with you, it was a fire in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. It was a two-person fire in 1954 was my first fire jump. So, I’m mistaken in thinking that ’70 was my first experience in the Selway. I guess I come by it very honestly, that fire and the Selway and Bob Mutch go all the way back to when I was in college in Michigan and smoke jumping out in Missoula. I think it was a little place called Hamby Point. HAMBY. You might check that on a map, but it was a little two-person fire, and I jumped with a veteran smoke jumper: Ed Wain on this fire, that was just a single snag that was struck by lightning, like so many fires are. It was easy to put a line around, and fell the snag, and put it out. We hiked out a couple of days later. That was interesting to discover for myself, that my roots go back in the Selway further than I had remembered. That’s the beauty of an oral history, I guess.

DL: So then in 1970, you returned? In what capacity then?

BM: In 1970, it was my more official and more long-lasting tie to the Selway-Bitterroot, My daughter at that time, yeah, 1970, born in 1960, she was ten years old. She loved the outdoors. I said, Linda, how would you like to go on a backpack trip this weekend into the Selway? So, we drive from Missoula 135 miles to Paradise, park at the guard station, hike up to Cooper’s Flat Cabin, eight and a half miles with our backpacks. Linda had a little Trapper Nelson pack, and she still rues the day that she had this uncomfortable, terrible, torture-rack pack as a little kid, going up Whitecap Creek for eight and a half miles. We got to Cooper’s Flat, and had a nice supper there, had use of the cabin. The next day, we made a day trip up high on a trail up behind Cooper’s Flat to a place called Vance Point. I took several pictures of Linda, and took pictures of Linda pointing the big fire scars on Ponderosa Pine. I used to go over there, you know, nights and weekends and summers. It was just Bob Mutch, and his forest. It did something. I always value programming, I’m sure, big time, and it stuck, and it really meant something to me. Talk about value programming, I just have to mention Linda, because I started out talking about Linda when she was ten. For those three years we were doing the Whitecap study, she liked that first backpack, even though she didn’t like the Trapper Nelson, and I had to get her a better pack. For many, many of my ten-day-on, four-day-off hitches that I did for the next two or three years, the next summer, I would ask Linda, would you like to go in with me, I’m going in for ten days, and I’d love to have your company. She went in with me at ten, eleven, twelve years old. I didn’t know this at the time… you talk about wilderness…

DL: Do you want me to stop it?

BM: No, I’m okay.

DL: You’re not the first person…

BM: You talk about wilderness and its effect on people, but this story always gets me, because wilderness is about nature, but just as important, it’s about people in nature, and the effect of nature on people, and the effect of people on nature. I didn’t know it at the time when Linda accompanied me on trip after trip in the Selway, actually helping me with my vegetation plot-work, and we’re in there ten days, and we camped out, and campfires at night, and backpacks, and freeze-dried meals, to the point where both of us were glad to get back to town for a milkshake after ten days in the woods. Some time in that period, or shortly after it, I went to hear a psychologist from the University of Colorado, Boulder, speak, and he was a very well-known psychologist, and he was very, very theatrical in his presentations. He was so good, that the Forest Service hired him to do workshops for Forest Service employees, because the title of at least one of his presentations that made such a huge impression on me, was simply this: You are what you were when. In other words, when we were nine, ten, eleven, twelve, we had little control over…we were value programming for the rest of our lives, and what we were exposed to at those young years were going to live with us for the rest of our lives, he said, unless someone gave you a significant emotional experience that somehow was able to change those views that were absolutely in your blood, and in your psyche. I realized when I heard him, because Linda grew up through high school years to become very excellent, you talked about English, and an English background, and an English career. Linda really enjoyed English. She became a great writer. She wrote lots of good things. She doesn’t have enough time now, but she likes to write poetry, and has written stories. But, as I read her themes in high school, I thought to myself, oh my god, the psychologist was right. Almost everything she wrote about went back to being ten, eleven and twelve with her dad in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness on this fire project. It was a love for nature, an appreciation for nature, knowing the names of plants and animals, being able to understand some of the interconnections. Understanding the importance of fire, and all this, because she got, at our campfire talks, she got to be an audience of one, and as her father probably went on too much for her, as he told stories about plants and animals, and their adaptations to fire, she went on to do her Master’s degree at the University of Arizona Tree-Ring Lab in a wonderful fire-related tree ring study on giant Sequoia trees. So, her initiation in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, I’m sure, made her who she is today.

DL: Are there any fire behaviors that the public isn’t… like if you had to say what some of interesting fire behaviors that you think are fascinating, but that most people don’t know about? What would those be?

BM: Yeah, there are some features. And yeah, I think you’re right that… Yeah, this might be, kind of way far out for a fire person, but I think, you know, fire phenomenon could be as fascinating of a wilderness resource as anything else you’re in wilderness for. In Yellowstone in ’88, for example, they went a long ways, even on very active fire days when Yellowstone was really burned over. Many of the fires there were allowed to burn, and finally many were suppressed, because there were too much. But people were allowed in Yellowstone to witness and see fires. One of my most memorable sights in Yellowstone—I was working there for a month with my daughter, who was then a Park Service employee, and working on the fires right along with me, in fact she met my plane from Washington DC when I landed in West Yellowstone. We were both in yellow shirts. Worked together there for a month, this little girl on the fires back there, what ’88 to 1960. She was 28 then. 28 years old, and we were working together. One of the most fascinating days… I mean it was the most fascinating event I’ve ever seen on a fire in my life. That’s 58 years, I guess, this year, thinking and working on fires. But we were in at Old Faithful, the day Old Faithful burned over by the North Fork Fire, and this fire that was started by two chainsaw… people cutting firewood over on the Targhee National Forest just south of West Yellowstone weeks earlier, and a spark from their chainsaw most likely started this fire. It started there, burned 4,000 acres. Before it was done, the Park Superintendent, who I highly admire, Bob Barbee, up in Mammoth at Park Headquarters, had to give an evacuation notice to his employees at Mammoth, miles away from where the fire started. If you’re familiar, West Yellowstone, the Mammoth Junction, then north to Gardiner. The fire went that far, and he was telling his people in Headquarters housing to get out, because the fire might come in to Park Headquarters. Well, on the seventh of September, Linda and I went in to Old Faithful Inn, because all eyes were focused on Old Faithful Inn. Old Faithful Inn is probably the world’s largest shake roof, and if anything was going to burn and make a media story, it would be Old Faithful Inn, burning to the ground in a fire in Yellowstone National Park, our first national park. So, we drove in there. We’d driven there earlier in the day, and not much was going on. A lot of tourists were there at noon. Sunny skies, and we left, and we drove back in about four o’clock, and by four o’clock, we looked off to the west, and there was smoke coming from the North Fork fire, and it was lined up squarely on the Old Faithful complex. It was pretty much deserted by then, but we went off by the geyser basin. There were firefighters everywhere. Went by the geyser basin, and there were some concession employees that hadn’t been evacuated, and they were huddled in the geyser basin, and this old, huge Old Faithful geyser basin was, you know, kind of gravel and stone. Nothing there that would burn. It was the safety zone at that point in time, and there were ABC, NBC, CBS had huge vans. There were huge dishes that were this big around aimed at the satellites. Everyone had their cameras focused on Old Faithful Inn, waiting for what they thought would be an unbelievable story, probably. They had a sprinkler system on the roof. There were sprinklers everywhere. There was just a deluge, a torrent of water coming off the eaves everywhere of this shake roof, because the Park Service was doing everything they could to keep this national icon from burning. So, Linda and I went over to… after we had made the rounds, and looked to see what was going on, we went into the safety zone. You didn’t have to be too smart to realize that’s where you wanted to be if you wanted to be safe, because there were 17 outbuildings that were destroyed in that afternoon at that very time. You could see that spot fire embers were going over the whole complex. They were landing a half-mile downwind from Old Faithful geyser basin, and they started a fire in Lodgepole Pine that was burning actively. People… I took some pictures of it… there were people… men and women, concession employees… they had bandannas around their face. They looked absolutely miserable. You could hardly see from me to you, the smoke was so bad. There were tears in their eyes from smoke irritation. In the midst of all of this, there was this huge roar. I mean an unbelievable roar. Someone said, oh, my God, is that the fire? Is the fire here? We all looked around, and someone else said, no, that’s Old Faithful going off. We can’t see it! The thermal heat… this is amazing. I actually wrote a poem about this 20 years later. I mean this poem just came out of nowhere, and I wrote this poem. I was there. In the poem, and at the time, too, I thought, wow, here’s this thermal heat, underground that goes off almost like clockwork. So regularly that the time is posted at the Inn when to go over there with your camera and get ready to take a picture, and everybody congregates like a magnet to Old Faithful. But that day, the thermal heat of a geyser basin was upstaged by the combustion heat of a Lodgepole Pine crown fire. It was absolutely lost in the Lodgepole Pine smoke. I thought, good for Lodgepole Pine.

DL: Right, there’s a lot of power in that.

BM: That was memorable enough, but that wasn’t the most memorable event. Later that evening, there were many of us there that wanted to get back to West Yellowstone because we were working. Area Command said no, you can’t go down until a Park Ranger escorts you back to Madison Junction, because there’s fire now, burning on both sides of the road, and we just can’t have cars, even official cars, going down there randomly. Someone could get in trouble, or there’s a lot of smoke. You could go off the road. So, we started down there, and there was an entourage behind us. It was a Park Ranger, and I forget her name now, but she had… she couldn’t manage us, at all, because we’d go a little ways down the road, and we got to the Fire Hole River, aptly named, that day, and on the far side of the Fire Hole River, there was this steep mountain slope across this meadow, and that whole mountain slope was going up in a crown fire. I mean, from top to bottom, it was an orange-red crown fire, and in the Fire Hole basin meadow, there was a herd of maybe 30-40 bison. They were single-file. They weren’t running in panic. They weren’t scared. They weren’t worried. They must have had genes that told them from way past that this is going to be okay. And you know their coat, it’s really dark brown, almost black. They must have been a perfect absorbing body for radiant heat. They must have felt the heat from that slope that was burning behind them, but they ambled along, they’d put a head down, they’d graze, they’d walk, they’d graze, they’d walk, they stayed pretty much single file, and what the Ranger had trouble… all of us of course would stop periodically. It was the picture of a lifetime. The elk and the crown fire in Yellowstone. We took picture after picture of this scene, and it was remarkable. She needed a cattle prod, because every once in a while, she’d come along by all this line of cars, and say no, we got to go now. The bison are trying to cross… there was a ford just ahead that we didn’t know about, and that’s where they were headed. She knew if we were there that we would interrupt them from crossing this ford. She knew their behavior that well. So, she finally got us down the road, but I tell you, that after seeing fire after fire after fire for decades, that image is indelibly inscribed in my memory as a wilderness resource. Bar none. Where are you going to see anything like that?

title: Naturally-Occurring Fire
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Naturally-Occurring Fire,” Bob Mutch tells us how changing fire management in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness led the way for new practices in wilderness all over the United States. Bob Mutch retired from a 38¬-year career in wildland fire research and management with the U.S. Forest Service in 1994. In the mid¬ 1950s, he worked as a Forest Service smokejumper in Missoula, MT. Bob later served 11 years as a Fire Behavior Analyst on a national Type 1 Fire Management Team. A highlight of his career was the development of the first Forest Service Plan to allow wildland fires to burn in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness to restore an important natural process.  Bob holds a Bachelor of Arts in Biology and English from Albion College in Michigan and a Master of Science in Fire Management (M.S.F.) degree from the University of Montana. In 2007, in acknowledgement of his ongoing accomplishments in the national and international wildland fire arenas, Bob was presented with an Honorary Doctoral Degree in Forestry from the University of Montana.

In this episode, Bob relates the story of the first wilderness “let burn” policy, beginning with his involvement in the fire study of the Whitecap Creek area of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Bob Mutch
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: April 14, 2011

DL: So, was the whitecap study area, was there a fire there already?

BM: No.

DL: Why did Bud choose that area?

BM: That’s interesting, yeah. I guess it could have been anywhere in this region. I guess it was partly chosen because there are landforms and vegetation types there that are represented through much of Region 1 of the Forest Service and the northern Rocky Mountains. We had open Ponderosa Pine savanna, pine trees and grass. We had north slope Grand Fir, Doug Fir, Lodgepole Pine communities. We had south slope Doug Fir, Ponderosa Pine, Doug Fir Communities. We had a large area, 54% was in the subalpine type, that high elevation country we love to backpack in, lots of granite rock and open vistas, and subalpine fir and White Bark Pine. So, it had it all. The Bitterroot… the feature on the Bitterroot is they had a Forest Supervisor that this wasn’t a casual interest. He wanted it. I mean, when you talk to Orville Daniels, you know this was really important to him, just from a philosophical standpoint for good land management, that it’s not right to suppress a natural process like fire in a wilderness, where fire has been molding the landscape for eons, for thousands of years. So, it had a good person to host it in Orville. It was like the fire lab and forestry sciences laboratory. We had some good research support nearby, and everyone agreed that this is a good place to do it. It also had a good… (this is important too) you wouldn’t want to pick and area that didn’t have any fires, especially if you’re going to allow lightning fires to burn. The records had been looked at, and lightning caused more than 90% of the fire starts back 45 years were started by lightning. So, it’s a natural outdoor laboratory, if there ever was one, both from a human standpoint, people committed and interested, from a vegetation standpoint, from a meteorological standpoint, that the lightning source was there. Indeed, when that plan was approved, we would have fires. When we had the plan approved, we would talk more about it a little bit later, the plan was approved two years later, the fire study started that year in ’70. We pretty well presented the plan to the chief of the Forest Service, John Maguire and his staff in July of ’72. Two years later we had a plan that was about that thick, and had all the do’s and don’ts, and had all the criteria, and how we’d manage fire, and which fires we might put out. The chief, almost on the spot in Washington DC, and we were all sitting around the big table; it was very formal. Just Orville and I, and gave him a briefing, and John went around the room, asked all of his staff what they thought of this, and not everyone was in accord.

DL: So were you nervous?

BM: Yeah, I was a little nervous, because he was well-respected in Forest Service circles. But we went around the room, and he raised that a little bit. Of course, I’d briefed Orville. Orville was able to cover the wilderness base as well, in a briefing before we’d even opened up the discussion. When it went around the room, this guy said a few things, but yeah, John Maguire before it was over said I like the sounds of what we’re doing, and we’re going to give you our verbal approval today, and you’ll be getting our final formal approval very quickly. I just say that, because two weeks later, my daughter Linda and I, I think it was early August; we were back in the wilderness doing some more vegetation work, and I got a call on my Forest Service radio. It was Hamilton Dispatch, through a repeater, and they said, Bob, we’ve just had a new lightning fire over in Bad Luck Creek. Here we are, only two weeks on a plan, and we had a fire. They said, we want you to hike out to Paradise, and we’re going to have a helicopter there. It’s maybe not the best from a wilderness standpoint, but they were treating it as an emergency, partly, and we could use helicopters for emergencies. They said there’ll be a helicopter there, and we’re going to take you over and drop you off, and we want your on-the-ground assessment of this fire. We’ve sort of tentatively decided it’s one that should burn, but we want you to take a look at it and report back before we give it our final approval. So, I was dropped off. I mean it was 24 feet by 24 feet. It was another, like my Hamby Creek fire. Another nothing fire. Another one of those lightning strikes, and a snag, and burning in a shrub field. In four days, it never got beyond 24 by 24 feet, and it went out. I mean, it just went out. There was a lesson there too, that sometimes there’s a knee-jerk reaction that every fire’s a bad fire. Well, maybe yeah, maybe not. In wilderness, most likely not. I had decided I didn’t need the helicopter, and they just continued on their other business and it wasn’t that far, and I hiked down to the Selway, and up to Paradise, and to the cabin where I’d left Linda for the day. I talked to the SO and Dispatch in Hamilton, and it was our first fire. Yeah, it was the Bad Luck Fire. Yeah, it was in Bad Luck Creek. Some thought that it wasn’t a very good name, but for our very first fire, but it turned out…

DL: So, What did you guys learn then? How long were you on that project, that study project?

BM: You know, we started in ’70 with the little introductory deal. Get acquainted. Got in the project area. The rest of ’70, ’71, ’72 we were doing all the field work. We did fire history work, to learn about the frequency of fires, looking at fire scars on Ponderosa Pine, that keeps fire scars intact going back two or three hundred years. We learned, like people learn everywhere from Ponderosa Pine, in Arizona, New Mexico, to Montana and Idaho, that in Ponderosa Pine, because of the flammability of the needles, and the fire behavior in Ponderosa Pine stands, that fires occur on the average, about every ten to fifteen years. There was that periodicity, frequency of fire, about every ten to fifteen years going back, say, two or three hundred years, all the way up to about 1900, 1910, 1920 when the Forest Service moves onto the scene and starts putting fires out. There’s an unbelievable marked decline in fire scars in Ponderosa Pine from that time forward. For decades, we kept fires out of a plant community where fires were part and parcel of the health of that community. We did fire history work, we did fuels work, we did fire behavior work, we had some hydrologists come in and do some stream work. After one of our fires, we had a fisheries… I think she was a… she was either a Master’s or a PhD student at the University of Montana, and she came in, and did a post-fire aquatic insect survey within the Fitz Creek Fire, downstream from where it started, and upstream where there was no fire effect, in about four or five miles of the riparian zone had burned pretty intensely, in the fire that summer of ’73, and she did a pretty detailed study of: was there any measurable effect of really heavy burning on aquatic insects above, in, and below the fire. Her conclusion as I remember it was that aquatic insects recolonize so quickly that she really couldn’t detect anything of significance. We did a soil… had a morphologist do some landscape work, identifying the various landscape types. These five vegetation zones I described to you earlier: shrub field, pine savannah, south slope, north slope and subalpine, those became… finally you get all this information, Debbie, and you think, wow, what does all this mean? What are we going to do? We’ve got to have some thread. We have to have some continuity. When it came down to putting the plan together, we had all these pieces of data, and all kinds of stuff. We started, and we laid it all out on these five geographical, ecological land units. We called them ELUs: Ecological Land Units. Landform, and soils, and vegetation, pretty much defining physically and biologically what they are, and what its capacity is. Finally… and fire behavior was different, obviously, in the subalpine, where it’s long winters, short summers, not very productive, not a lot of plant growth, not a lot of fuels over time, like there is in the north slope, a more moist community. So, fire behavior, fuels, fire history, natural breaks due to rock formations, and things like that… all kind of fit together like pieces in a puzzle. We decided to put it all together, and we suddenly realized that we can be very liberal up here in the 54% that is subalpine. It’s high, like that Sequoia/King’s Canyon. They drew a line at 7,000 feet and said that anything above it is pretty much free to do what it wants to do, with some limitations. So, the pieces fit together, and the Doug Fir, Ponderosa Pine south slope unit, where we identified frequent fire, and then no fire, we realized that… and there were a lot of ladder fuels in the absence of fire, a lot of Douglas Fir grows up that would have been killed by those fires every ten or twelve years. The stands were not as open as they would have been historically. There’s more fuel. There was enough more fuel in the crown fire potential, where the typical historical fire would have been a low-intensity surface fire, because fires burn so often, there wasn’t a lot to burn. If you’re burning every ten years… So, we realized that we had the most effect through fire suppression on that south slope Ponderosa Pine/Douglas Fir unit, and we were most conservative in our prescriptions there, meaning that we didn’t allow any fires starting at the beginning of the fire season to burn there. We just put in more or less a calendar date. So, if it was late in the fire season, and we didn’t have months, we just had weeks, maybe, left in the fire season, before wet weather would start in late August, early September, at that point on the calendar, we would begin to evaluate those fires with the thought that we could allow some to burn gradually getting to the point as we get fires over time where you wouldn’t have to draw those kinds of conclusions, and be that conservative any more. Which we didn’t do after a while, so the pieces fell together that way. It was fun to put it together. It seemed to make sense. Most the people that we talked to thought it was a good idea. Not everybody did. There was a Western… I wish I would have brought a copy of that journal with us… there’s a Western Wildland… It’s one I could send you if you really want to see it, but a special journal put out by the University of Montana Forestry school, and they covered different issues. I think it was quarterly. This particular issue was a fire issue, and it was after our Fitz Creek Fire of ’73. It had just came out. I had an article in it titled “I Thought Forest Fires Were Black.” One of our field assistants came in two weeks after… his girlfriend came in. Two weeks after the fire was over, and the shower of Ponderosa Pine needles, some of it natural fall needle drop anyway, Ponderosa Pine, you know, drops the older needles every fall, but some of it was scorched needles coming down. This surface of that Ponderosa Pine savannah area that the trail goes up through to Bad Luck Lookout… the whole forest area that had been black two weeks earlier, was now a golden mantle of pine needles. She hiked in there with us. We were going up the trail to the lookout tower, and she said to Tim, Tim, I thought forest fires were black! She said these are golden. In fact, there was such a carpet of golden needles that if someone… if there had been an ignition source, you could have had another fire over this mantle of golden Ponderosa Pine needles two weeks after the first fire went through that stand. Anyway, that was one article. Bud Moore has an article in there, and Orville Daniels has an article in there, all talking to this experience of the change in philosophy and thinking of the Forest Service towards fire.

DL: So, was the Whitecap study program a kind of first then?

BM: It really was. It was the pilot project in the Forest Service. As you know now, the Park Service had preceded this effort, getting their park lightning fire plan approved in 1968. That was partly due to the Starker-Leopold report. Starker was that professor at UC Berkeley, who wrote kind of a white paper for the Park Service. You should be managing for the natural processes, the natural systems. Suppressing fire is one of the most unnatural things you could be doing. That was their impetus, to get them going. Our impetus was the Wilderness Act of 1964 that Bud Moore or Bill Warf was so instrumental… he wrote kind of the guidelines on how the Forest Service would implement the Wilderness Act. He was called back to Washington to write the regulations that directed the Forest Service from that point forward. How will it implement the Wilderness Act in Forest Service Wilderness? So, he was a student of that act, and of course Bud had the visions for fire: it needs to be on the land, not removed from the wilderness, and Orville the dedicated Forest Supervisor, and lucky Dave and I to go on the ground for two or three years or so. To answer the rest of your question, there we were, two years later, had the approval in July. First small fire that August ’72. Next year, big fire, started in July of… I think it was July or early August of ’73.

DL: That’s the Fitz Creek Fire?

BM: That’s the Fitz Creek fire. Then, we continued some of our monitoring evaluation work. I stayed kind of tied to the effort probably through the rest of ’73, ’74, ’75… working out of the fire lab. Dave was somewhat still involved out of the Bitterroot. Just kind of keeping tabs of what was going on in there. It was…now it’s to the point where it was just like a brush fire that started in the Bad Luck Creek brush field, in ’72, allowed to burn, like brush fires do, if the idea’s right. This germ was well-fertilized, and pretty soon the whole Selway had a plan. Piece by piece: first it was Whitecap, then it was Moose Creek, then it was up on the Clearwater part.

DL: Do you mean like the Moose Creek District?

BM: Moose Creek District. Was added later. Yeah, the whole district went under a plan. The rest of the Bitterroot and the West Fork District went under a plan. The Bitterroot was kind of piecemeal, where once this caught on, then the Heatley Wilderness in New Mexico, and the Boundary Waters Canoe area was another one to follow shortly afterward, to the point now where I would imagine most large wildernesses in the Forest Service have a fire management plan.

DL: That’s… So, the conclusion that I’m drawing is that if wilderness were to go away, then let burn policy would go away, and that would be a really big loss for the environment.

BM: Part of the story we haven’t told yet, to answer the rest of your question… the thing that’s interesting about wilderness fire is that it was so right for wilderness that it has been exported outside wilderness. We are using it in large tracts of land where we can have a plan to allow fire to burn outside wilderness to achieve other benefits, not the wilderness resource benefits; maybe it’s wildlife, maybe it’s hazard reduction, maybe it’s aesthetically desirable to have some fires, maybe it’s to sustain plants and animals outside wilderness that are fire-dependent. So, there have been some really good examples of extending this idea to lands outside wilderness as well. So, that’s one lesson that we learned and applied. There’s another lesson that I don’t think any of us, none of the original five ever envisioned when we started this snowball rolling downhill, that this would be an outcome, and it’s a very satisfying outcome to the program. And what we’ve discovered now that we’ve allowed fires to burn year after year, decade after decade for three-plus decades now, under all kinds of weather conditions, all kind of fire behavior conditions, from low to moderate to high to very high, even to extreme fire danger conditions, that if the conditions are rights, we’ve had some fire burning in wilderness even then. Those fires burning under every conceivable kind of weather and fuels and topography have left us a legacy on the landscape. Some have called it, I think one was Penny Morgan at University of Idaho who’s such a good fire ecologist. She calls it a fire-smart landscape. Meaning simply this: that now we’ve learned finally that when we allow a fire to burn, in 2004 or 2005 or 2006, those fires are being self-regulated by previous fires that have been allowed to burn the landscape. In other words, Mother Nature has been rolling the dice now so long in the Selway-Bitterroot the fuels have been broken up into such a mosaic of recent, sort of recent, not-so-recent, thirty years ago recent… fuels and mosaics and vegetation situations that now, when we have a fire, a fire this year is going to burn into a fire of some recent past. The fire behavior is going to change drastically, and the fire may not go out, but it’s going to change dramatically in character, and where we used to be concerned, and we still should be concerned about a fire burning across the wilderness boundary into lands outside wilderness and causing unwanted effects, we don’t want that to happen, but the fires are sort of taking care of themselves now, which is, to me, a wonderful footnote to this whole story.

DL: It is, yeah.

title: Fish Lake Disasters
introduction: In this episode, titled “Fish Lake Disasters,” we hear stories of some of the plane crashes at Fish Lake.  The Fish Lake airstrip is located at the southwest end of Fish Lake, which boasts an altitude of 5,646 feet.  Although beautiful, the location can pose a deadly threat to pilots who attempt to take off under the wrong conditions.  Besides being a wilderness pilot himself, Allan Renshaw has worked with his brother Jim as an outfitter based at the Fish Lake camp.  Here, he shares stories of the plane wrecks in Fish Lake, and of wilderness pilots that he and his brother knew personally.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Allan Renshaw
Interviewer: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Date: March 22, 2011
Location: Cambridge, Idaho

DL: You mentioned that there are a number of airplanes in Fish Lake. Can you talk about how many you think there are, and some of the reasons why they’re there?

AR: Well, I know the history of some of them. The first one that crashed was an Air Coupe. That was an aircraft that had the unique ability to be flown only by the yoke. You didn’t have to have rudder pedals. It was interconnected. Underpowered, and really should not have been at Fish Lake at 5,000 foot. I mean, sea level elevation, and by the time you add in the temperature and everything, well, the density-altitude was much greater. That airplane made it completely across the lake, since the lake butted into the airport, and crashed on the other side in some rocks. For a number of years, you could ride by, and you could see the aluminum parts of that airplane. Jim was there at one point in time when an aircraft took off and crashed into the lake again, during the heat of the day, when they shouldn’t have been flying. Someone was close to the lake and other fishermen, and I can remember that Jim hopped onto a horse bareback with some ropes, and galloped that horse all the way down more than a mile and a half to the point where the airplane could be seen with the tail sticking up out of the water. The fishermen down there was a swimmer, and I think the story goes that they took a log or something, and ropes out to the airplane, tied it to the tail, and then he dove to try to retrieve the occupants, and was unsuccessful. You know, you can wind-break a horse by pushing them too hard, and Jim did that with that particular horse. That was not a healthy thing to do. Another aircraft took off, and I wasn’t there, but I got in on the aftermath of it all. It was a Super Cub with two people, and they made it off the ground. He couldn’t climb high enough to get over the trees at the end of the lake, but he had enough room to make a circle around the lake. Now why he decided not to bank back to the airport and set down, I don’t know. I suspect that he was a better pilot than I was. He came back around, and decided I’m going to make this, so I’m going to put it in close to shore. So he put it into a slip, and slid it within probably fifteen feet of the shore, and set it into the water. Both of those guys walked out of there. Now, that airplane sat there for a while, and that fall, while I was packing and guiding, and had a little bit of time on my hands, I went down to look at it. The engine had already been removed. The electronics had been removed. The only thing that was there was the pilot’s seat, and I was thinking, boy, we need something soft to sit on at camp. So, I was in there taking this thing apart, and we had a hunter that was a moose hunter, no an elk hunter, that was across the lake. He may have had his fishing pole with him at the time, because… I think he was… he was fishing over there. I didn’t know he was there. There was a moose that came up the little spot of land behind him, and had him trapped. He was off over there waving to me, and trying to get my attention, and I was oblivious. I had no idea he was over there. Went on about my work of removing the seat, and taking it back to camp. I heard about that that night from that fellow. There was no way that I could have helped him, but he was definitely in distress. There must have been either eight or nine aircraft that crashed into that lake, all of them because of density-altitude.

DL: Can you explain what Density-Altitude is?

AR: As the air becomes heated, it has less molecules available to create the lift to the wing that is necessary. I witnessed some very close calls. A group of hunters flew in with a 182, landed, and they were loaded to the hilt. There were four people in there, and they had all of their gear. They let one person out while they went to search an area that they might hunt on. Came back and landed, and decided they would go to Moose Creek. As the fellow was standing there beside, me, I said, you know, when he comes back and picks you up, just as a private pilot, I would suggest that you wait a few hours before you take off. Well, that pilot knew better than I, and he got in, and they took off all right, but they used every bit of that runway to get off the ground, and very lucky to have made it. Another time was when Lee Atkins was flying elk for us, out of Fish Lake, and we had some snow on the ground. It was just enough snow that he couldn’t quite get it off the ground. He made three passes down the runway, and at the windsock, he would shut it down, and then you could see him just sliding, and slowing it down, and then he would turn around and come back. He got out of the airplane, and came over, and you couldn’t tell that he was shaken up at all. You knew he was nervous enough because he shut the airplane down, then he came over to talk to me. He says, okay, I’m going to try it one more time, and if it’s not off of the ground by the time I hit the air sock, I’m just going to have to unload part of this, and leave. Fortunately, he got off the ground and left. But he was calling it close. Another airplane experience at Fish Lake was one fall when someone flew in from Florida with a rented Cessna 180 plane. He was taken out to a spite camp, but before he went out, he was talking with a family friend of ours, and helper, Stan Heppler, who had been a pilot, and had many hundreds of thousands of hours under his belt. He said, Stan, if you want to use the airplane, the key’s on the dipstick, just go ahead. We had another person there who was trying to find a moose. Stan said, let’s go out and search. We can see where they are, and then come back and tell him (because it’s illegal to spot game from an aircraft, and then immediately contact the hunter). So, one morning bright and early, we went down to the airport, and Stan and I got into the aircraft, and I know better. He should have known better. It was cold that morning. Very cold. He primed the engine, and it wouldn’t start. He primed it a second time. It wouldn’t start. He was an experienced pilot, and he should have known better. He primed it a third time. It spit and sputtered, and then we had a flame in the engine. I jumped out, and ran to the cabin at Fish Lake, grabbed the fire extinguisher on the outside; he reached under the pilot’s seat and got that one. We got the fire out. But you can’t fly an airplane that’s been on fire. So, that airplane sat on the runway for about a week while a mechanic was flown in from Orofino, and they pulled it up to the cabin, and they raised the engine out of it, and tore the whole thing apart, and put it back together. It was a good thing that that pilot had renter’s insurance, because I’m sure that it cost him $20,000. That was…

DL: Could you just tell someone maybe who hasn’t been to Fish Lake why getting up is difficult, like it’s in a canyon, right?

AR: It’s a one-way airstrip for most pilots. One or two people have landed the opposite way, but it’s not recommended. You know, one of the reasons that it’s a little bit difficult getting up is because you do have a lake at the end of it, and air temperature changes there. So, you want to be off the ground, and then you can fly down the canyon if you would like. It’s the difference in altitude, density-altitude, and the change in temperature over the lake that makes it critical that you get altitude in a hurry.

DL: And then you have to fly over… saddles, and peaks?

AR: Well, you do, but you also have the opportunity of going down the Lochsa, if necessary, and many times, pilots did that in the fall when the cloud cover was low. They would scud-run, if you wish. That was always interesting. Coming out of Moose Creek, I flew out with a pilot one time in a Super Cub. It was below the cloud level, and it started snowing on us. So, as we were flying down the river canyon, there were several opportunities to make a wrong turn. You could either turn up Meadow Creek, or you could turn up Gedney Creek, or you could stay with the river. As we were going, he would be flying, and I would say, right, or left, and he would immediately correct, which was probably what happened with Joe Rosencrantz out of Moose Creek Ranches, who left one fall and it was not good weather, and he flew down the river, and crashed… the story was that he’d had all the money from people there at Moose Creek Ranches with him, and rumors spread that he had escaped the country, and there was a big search for him. I think they had the National Guard out. They had… I know that Stan Heppler was on the search. It gave me an opportunity over the years after that, because his plane wasn’t located for I don’t know, 20 years or so?

JH: At least.

AR: To look in all of the various places that would’ve hidden an airplane. I was consciously riding and looking… hmmm… in a lake? How about that brush patch? You know, always looking for evidence. They did find him off of Gedney Creek, and some of the hunters that were in that area that night… a few years later, I learned, had heard something down in that area. This was from Phil Robinette’s relatives. It was probably the crash. They were a mountainside over, so, a drainage over.

title: Wilderness Childhood
introduction: In this episode, titled “Wilderness Childhood,” Allen Renshaw tells us what it was like to spend his young childhood in the backcountry.  Growing up at the Selway Lodge shaped Allan’s future, first as a backcountry fire patrol pilot, and later, as a speech therapist.  He took the lessons about helping others that he learned from his parents in the wilderness and spent a lifetime helping children in Idaho school districts.  Listen as Allan shares stories of his early childhood at the Selway Lodge.
