orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Allen Renshaw
Interviewer: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Date: March 22, 2011
Location: Cambridge, Idaho

AR: Well, okay. I was born in Kooskia, Idaho to Alvin and Elna Renshaw, who owned the Selway Lodge. Spent the first 8 years, and a little bit over, of my life kind of off and on at the Selway Lodge, between there and Kooskia. We did have a hunting and fishing lodge, and Dad spent his time serving guests there. He was also involved with packing for the Forest Service from time to time. So, I became involved with the clients that were there. Sometimes getting in their way, I’m sure, as a young child. The stay at the Selway Lodge was a unique experience, because I was the youngest of the family by 8 years, younger than my brother, my nearest sibling. That in and of itself has created a difference in memories, of experience between Jean and Jim and my sister Billie and I. The experience there was unique in the fact that not only was I growing up kind of as a lonely, well, maybe not lonely, but only child. But having just the freedom to kind of do what I wanted to do, and experience the clients that came from a wide variety of backgrounds and experiences, and of the one experience with the prisoners of war that were stationed at Bear Creek, the ranger station just downriver from the Selway Lodge. As they were redoing the bridge that crossed the Selway River. I was one that was surrounded by people that had pistols and rifles, and so I had my own pop guns, and I can remember one day sitting out on the… or standing out on the porch and seeing the prisoners of war cross the river on the sand bar, and probably taking a break, and I was going bang, bang, bang, bang, bang! Looking back on it now, I was thinking gee, this is war time. Prisoners of war. That probably wasn’t taken too well. Some of them were extremely of good natured. One of them fell over in the sand, and the others covered him up with sand. A couple more grabbed a couple of sticks and made a cross and stuck in the sand over his head. I thought wow! This is fun, and they’re kind of playing with me. The next day I walked out onto the bridge with my little pop-gun. It was a cap gun type of affair, and was going bang, bang, bang, bang, expecting the same thing, and actually one of them laid down on the sand, but there was one individual who came up on the bridge, and says lemme see your pistol. I handed it over to him. He proceeded to throw it into the river. Well, I heard this outcry from the people in the sand, and a couple of them came up, and chewed him out, and dove into the river to retrieve my pistol. Looking back on it now, I guess, and with a little bit of information from my siblings, that particular prisoner was not Italian like the rest of them, but a German. Took much offense at me shooting. It must have been a week or two after all of that, that the prisoners were taken out to town, why, I have no idea, but returned and one of the Italian prisoners had a small suit of clothes that was designed to replicate naval people. It was for his son, actually. But he came over and gave it to me. I think maybe this was kind of his way of saying I’m sorry for the incident that happened. I have no idea where that suit is located now, but that was pleasing. It was a very rewarding experience.

DL: Do you know where these prisoners were stationed when they weren’t building? Were they just kind of shuttled around the country to different projects? Do you know much about that history?

AR: I don’t know that much about that. They may have come out of the Missoula area, because I know there was a Prisoner of War camp in Missoula. I understand that they were Merchant Marines, and that they were essentially detained in port in California, and then shipped to the back woods of Idaho. No, there’s not too much information that I have about them.

DL: Wow, that’s really interesting. So, I understand, you have a couple bear stories, or at least one that you can tell us about.

AR: Oh, yes. There was a point in time when my dad was building a meat house. You needed someplace to keep meat cool, and the flies away from it, and so forth, until it was transported out. He was utilizing shakes, long shakes, to build the sides and the roof, and some wire around for the cooling. He had cut down a cedar tree in Ditch Creek. We were to… Jim and I… were to go up to the tree, and pack down the shake bolts. The long pieces of cedar that were to be split into shakes. This one particular trip, I think I talked myself into it. I don’t know that Jim really wanted me along. I was ahead on my horse, Midget, and Jim was following behind with his pack-string. We had a young cocker spaniel named Rusty. Rusty always had her nose down, and was searching all over the territory, and ran ahead of us up the trail. Well, pretty soon, we saw Rusty coming, running back around this outside turn of the trail, and right behind her was a big, black bear. All at once… both of us stopped. I mean, here we were, the bear was coming, and then suddenly stopped. The pack string and all of the horses stopped. We were wondering what’s going to happen next? Because Rusty had run between all of the legs of the horses and the mules, back behind, to get out of the way of the bear. Jim says, start yelling. So we started yelling. The bear kind of looked at us, and pretty soon walked off the trail. This was a mother bear, we discovered, because she had sent her cubs up a tree, and she got her cubs down, and they crossed the drainage and up the other side. So, we could have had pandemonium there if the bear had continued coming, and although I was on a very gentle horse, that gentle horse would have probably have not liked to have met that bear. That shook us up, and remains in my memory. There was another time when there was a bear that kept coming in around our house, around the lodge. The dogs would go out and bark like everything. It was always in the evening, it seemed. We had some hunters that had just arrived, and they were distributed to the various guest cabins, and we were in the living room around the fire, enjoying conversation, and the heat of the stove, and the dogs started barking. Dad says, it’s that bear. Says, you guys go get your guns. We’ll see if we can’t get this bear. The dog chased the bear down across the yard, and up a tree near the river’s edge. Two of the hunters went down and shot at the bear, and the bear fell down at the base of the tree. Since it was dark, there really wasn’t any light down there to dress the bear out, so they got a great, big tub, or washtub, and went down, loaded the bear into the tub, brought it up in front of the porch, and laid it out to dress it, and Dad reached down to cut its throat, the first thing that you generally do. It opens its eyes. They had only grazed it. Here this bear was coming to, and Dad says, go get my pistol. Well, somebody ran to get the pistol. I was on the porch. I ran in and crawled under the bed while he finished off the bear. Now, it really wasn’t a danger, I guess, but I wasn’t going to take any chances!

DL: That’s great, yeah. You guys had a few neighbors… I mean the neighbors were miles away, but can you talk about your relationships with the people at Running Creek and North Star during those years? Who was there, and how did you interact… on what occasions?

AR: I was fairly young when I was there. The Horrace boys were living upstream, and also…

DL: At Running Creek?

AR: At Running Creek. And the Wolfenbargers had North Star. Olie would come down frequently. Punk would come down… his son would come down frequently. The Horrace boys… you know, I think I met them a couple of times, but I can remember one time spending some time at their house with our family. It was obviously… it had to do with cattle, because it was probably our cattle, and maybe part of their cattle, and it was during the summertime, so there was probably… they needed to have some salt put out to them or something. The Horrace boys had a garden, just outside of their cabin. I mean just outside of their cabin. They had a rather interesting weeder. It ran on a wheel, and a couple of times it ran into the ground, and you’d push that along in front of you. I was out there trying that out one day, and it hit something. It stopped me suddenly, and I had been listening to the vocabulary of adults for some time, and tried using a lot of that vocabulary. Unfortunately, or perhaps fortunately, right outside of the window of my… of the cabin my mother and father were in. My father came out, and let’s put it succinctly, tanned my hide. I no longer used that vocabulary in front of him. That same cabin, the memory is clear on some of the things that they had there. Number one, it was a long cabin. So you entered a porch, and then the main living room/kitchen/dining room area, then beyond that was a smaller room, was the bedroom. Very dark. I don’t even know if it had a window into. There were at least two, perhaps three beds in there. Out on the porch was a small apparatus that I was to learn was to make candles with. That image has stayed in my mind all of these years. It was something that you poured beeswax into after you strung the wicks thorough, and then turned it upside down, and then it had the ability to open, and there you had a candle.

DL: So, I get the impression that you and your siblings are uncommonly close, for siblings. Do you think that has anything to do with that time you spent at Selway Lodge?

AR: I think the general experience of living there certainly has something in common. Close? Well, I don’t know about that. Depends what you mean by close. Closeness? Yeah. I’ll keep ‘em.

DL: I guess I was just thinking how a particular piece of land keeps people together, and not just you and your siblings, but you and your spouse, and your children, and there is sort of an intergenerational legacy created because of that piece of land.

AR: There is that, certainly. Because they’ve all heard the stories of the Selway. It’s…It gives them a sense of heritage, and that was started with Mom and Dad. It started much earlier than that, because his dad was on the Selway. And did packing and guiding, and so it’s one of the reasons that the drainage Renshaw Creek was named, after them. I know that my dad and my grandfather had probably experienced the Upper Selway country too, and it’s a sense of curiosity, and it’s a sense of pride, that they existed in that area, and they existed, I think, with a certain amount of integrity. That doesn’t mean that they didn’t do things that they shouldn’t have done. But the combination of people that we ran into, Forest Service workers… when we were first in there in the early 40’s, and 30’s, there was a sense of helping one another that came through very strongly. I think that society has led us a little bit away from that now. That’s kind of sad. You know, where else do you get away from the distractions of modern life? Where else do you experience the smells of pine trees? The sound of crows? Along the river, the sound of river, and the awareness that as you climb a hill, away from the river, the sense of silence then. Where else do you find the opportunity to sit in the saddle and be with yourself and dream? It’s a little bit like going to church.

title: The Big Storm
introduction: In this episode, titled “The Big Storm,” we listen to Mack Bohrmann tell the story of a wilderness storm, one of many natural elements that users experience while out in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness.  Mack was born and raised in Yarmouth, Maine, and moved out to Missoula, Montana in 2004 to attend the University of Montana, where he received a degree in Anthropology and Linguistics, and a minor in Natural Development Studies.  Two months later, Mack found himself working for the Montana Conservation Corps, which is an AmeriCorps program, and was leading six people who had never been in the woods before, for six months in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness.    Stories like Mack’s make up the backbone of the Selway-Bitterroot oral history, as they’re recounted again and again around campfires in the backcountry, and most people who have lived or worked in the wilderness quickly learn the value of telling a good story.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Mack Bohrmann
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, MT
Date: April 20, 2011

MB: And then you find yourself writing letters at Moose Creek on the table, and you’re writing the same thing over and over again. You’re like, this hitch I saw five bears. I’m okay, though. Bears aren’t scary. And you’re writing all this stuff to people who don’t have any idea. I picture zooming out. Like there’s certain people here in Missoula who know what wilderness is, and know that I use crosscuts and not chainsaws, and know why. Then there’s people back in New England, where I’m from, who have no idea about wilderness, no idea about Idaho, and that’s the hardest part about… the hardest part for me was… coming out of both ears was… all these crazy stories. Not even stories, just like feelings, like, I don’t know. Feelings that are the only way to feel at that point. People are like… you come out, like so, how was it? You’re like, I can’t put this in a tiny box for you. Trying to put it in a tiny box undermines every aspect of why I go out there, because it’s an all-encompassing, pervasive thing in my life. But people are like, oh, so what happened? Like, where were you on the Fourth of July? I don’t know where I was on the Fourth of July! Probably working. So, it’s good to have… that’s the negative side, but people who are… who do know what crosscuts are, and what Wilderness is, with a capital “W”… those are great people to talk to. That’s what I realize, going into the woods, is we don’t see a lot of people out there, but the people we do see out there, are some of the most quality people.

DL: So, can you think of any experiences where you’ve had to depend on people in ways that you don’t in the front country? Or vice versa?

MB: Yeah, definitely. Last year, we were at Isaac Lake, and it was, what, July 31st, and there hadn’t been a thunderstorm yet. This was a long day for us. We started at East Moose. We hiked up Double Ridge, and we were just cutting trees. We were going to camp at Double Ridge. There were these… there used to be a lookout there, but they just took the lightning rod off of it and it blew up. There’s tons of glass all over the place. We were going to camp there, but geographically, we looked at it, and it’s kind of in a bend in East Moose. Not an elbow bend, but still a bend, and all the weather that came from the west (that’s where the weather comes from) was spraying right into this ridge, and we decided that we’d radio the LAL, the Latent Activity Level. All that stuff was telling us it was probably better not to camp at this spot, probably better to move on. We moved on to… it was like an eight-mile day, like but it was like the hardest day I ever hiked. We started off by… it’s like 2300 feet to… 7000 feet, then down to 6000 feet. We’re hiking through snow at the end of it. Long day. Anyways, we showed up to Isaac Lake. We sit down; we eat dinner; we go to bed, like pragmatic, just like… Trail crews get along best when they’re working hard. Like construction crews hate each other because they look at each other all day. Cut and run crews move and cover ground; they’re too tired to argue. It’s a beautiful thing. So, we were just reveling in that, that we were just too tired to argue with each other, and just, like timing was just impeccable. It started to drip, drip, drip. We were like oh, like, here comes rain. Then the roll of thunder comes from the west. We were like oh my God, here it comes. Then… I can’t even… I wish I could draw… I can’t draw. I don’t know. Paint. If I was artistic… I need to articulate this somehow, this camping at Isaac Lake that night, and then hearing the cells moving. I said I was going to get out of my tent, but where do you go? I’ve actually done research, because I’m afraid of lightning, and if I’m afraid of things, I research them, so I figured out… the literature… there’s no safe place outside. So, like, I went to like a stand of trees which were all similar size, and I watched about a hundred yards away lightning strike trees and blowing up trees and this blue-green color… I’d never seen such crazy colors. This was at… five cells came through. They would last fifteen minutes. A half-hour break, and another cell would come through. Just a pattern of the onset of the cell was driving rain, hail, wind, sideways wind, and up-and-down wind. Lightning every five seconds would be conservative, I think. There was a lot of lightning. It was like all of the pent-up energy from the whole season was just releasing in one storm. I didn’t sleep very much that night. Back to where this came from is the culture out there… usually we do check-ins at eight o’clock, but at six o’clock in the morning, we’re all… the ranger at Moose Creek was on radio, checking us, because she knew where we were, checking the other trail crew, but there was still no contact from Shissler Lookout. We’re like, where is Laura? What is she doing up there? Finally, she gets on, and we’re like, Laura, how was your night up there? She…

DL: Laura is the lookout?

MB: Laura’s the lookout at Shissler, and she said that at nine pm, she got a call from Indian Hill Lookout, which is west of her, saying, Laura, get on your stool, turn off your radio. Her stool has glass on it, and it’s insulated. She said all of a sudden, sideways hail, driving wind. She got on her stool, and her hair was standing on end, and she was watching… she had her azimuth in front of her, and she was watching electricity arc between everything, buzzing, Saint Elmo’s Fire, watching ground strikes, trying to write them, where they were. She was smoking cigarettes, because she was trying to do anything to make herself relax. This was all night. She didn’t sleep at all until the morning. But that was really cool to get on the radio and everyone was looking out. Everyone was really worried. Everyone was… because that was a hell of a storm. People in Missoula saw it, and it was… I don’t know. And the next morning everyone was hung over from thunder and lightning and not sleeping. Even the animals were out, and it was such a weird day. We decided then to call in that hitch a little early, and went back to the station for the Fourth of July.

DL: So, you do know where you were on Fourth of July?

MB: Mmm-hmmm. I DO know where I was on Fourth of July.

DL: Wow, so, were you thinking, that’s going to be a lot of trail to clear?

MB: Yeah. But mostly I was just thinking about myself at that point. It definitely was a paradigm shift. Sitting in my tent, I was like do I really want to get out of my tent? No, I don’t want to get out of my tent. What are the odds of being struck by lightning? Odds? No idiot has been where I am right now. There’s no way you can deduce odds. I figured out that the odds are like 1 in 700,000 of being struck by lightning, but no one was camped basically in Isaac Lake, up at 6,000 feet in a lightning storm. There’s no… So that was actually a really good thought. It was a really good epiphany for me. You know what? No one’s been here. And I’ve been in a lot of places where no one’s been. And people have been in a lot of places where I haven’t been. So the probability needs to be taken with a grain of salt. Look where you are; don’t look at the numbers of what’s happened where you are.

DL: Yeah, wow.

title: Wilderness Education
introduction: In this episode, titled “Wilderness Education,” Connie Saylor tells the story of the wilderness that drew her from Iowa where she was a schoolteacher. Since 1988, Connie has worked for the Forest Service in the Clearwater National Forest and the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. She did not lose her role as a teacher; instead she applied it to her work in the wilderness, organizing workshops to introduce teachers and students to wilderness, teaching guests about low-impact recreation, and building connections between the classroom and the wilderness. Connie was instrumental in helping to form the Selway-Bitterroot Frank Church Foundation as an early field leader and in training interns. Today, Connie still loves wilderness deeply, and works to educate others on the importance of preserving wild land for future generations to enjoy.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Connie Saylor
Interviewers: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Date: May 6, 2011
Location: Nezperce, Idaho
Topic: Education in Wilderness

DL: So, Connie, how did you first come to this area, the Selway-Bitterroot area?

CS: It was a big chance. I was living in Iowa, that’s where I was born, and I was in a workshop called American Wilderness Leadership School. Now Iowa is one of the six states that does not have wilderness so it’s pretty foreign to that part of the country although I was a rural person and grew up in the country and that’s why I learned to love the land. But I was in a Wilderness Leadership School and there was a young woman there, it was the very first one in Iowa as a matter of fact, there was a young woman there, Jill, and she had been a lookout at Powell Ranger Station because her brother had come out from Iowa and he was living in Lolo so she came out for a summer and worked at the Bear Mountain Lookout. You know Bear Mountain. And she had taken some photographs and she had those with her. She showed me these photographs and I was just overwhelmed, something went wang in my heart and it was I have to be in this place. Just right then: I have to go there. And I remember driving out of the driveway and I thought damn this is the stupidest thing you ever did, you better just turn around and go back to little Essex, Iowa, and not do this anymore and I almost turned around but I headed west. So I took my time driving along the way. I stopped at Cabellas. It’s back before Cabellas was the gigantic thing it is now. They only had two stories then. So I stopped and I spent a half a day at Cabellas buying a sleeping bag, a hat, and whatever I thought I needed. I wasn’t sure all the gear that you needed but I still sleep in that sleeping bag to this day. So I drove on out and I stayed in cheap motels a couple of nights along the way. I remember seeing an antelope give birth to a fawn I guess you call them along the way and I was just enjoying the scenery and I got to the summit between Montana and Idaho, you know, at the top and I got out of the pickup and I said here I am. I almost kissed the ground but I thought okay and then it said Clearwater National Forest and I said this is where I’m going to work. So my first 10-day hitch I went in with the pack string and even though I lived on a farm and had been around animals a lot I really wasn’t that familiar with mules, now we raise them. And I helped the packer get my stuff together and was just fascinated with the whole procedure of packing which I later learned to do myself to my amazement. And we were busy and he pointed up to the hills and he said see up there and I said yah. He says it’s snowing there. He said that’s where we’re going. Okay. One thing I do remember driving down the highway I was looking up into the hills, now this is really dumb, but it was so steep. It was just so steep and I thought well there’s no way you can get up in there. I didn’t know there were roads there. I didn’t know there were trails there. I thought where am I going to work. You can’t negotiate those hills. Now that’s pretty dumb. But there I was in the middle of them for several more years. So the packer put me on a big tall mule and we took off for Horse Camp which is about a 10 mile trip up Boulder Creek that drains into the Lochsa and there’s a little cabin back there called Horse Camp, see there’s a picture of it right there. That’s Horse Camp, yah. And he dumped me off and said I’ll see you in 10 days. So I said okay and I really didn’t have any direction or orientation into this job. So they dumped me off all by myself. I had a map and all of my hitches were by myself until I, I had never been there, of course, before so I had to just figure it out on my own and I probably learned things better by doing that than someone saying, leading me by the hand. I had some huge learning experiences that I obviously lived through but.

DL: That’s good. So how do your teaching and wilderness merge like for you? What’s the cross-over?

CS: I think it was a natural thing because part of my job description was education which meant I was to make visitor contacts in the woods and I was to spread the message of low impact camping and to educate the public who used the wilderness about what wilderness really is and why we expect certain rules to be followed in the wilderness and part of it’s the philosophy of wilderness and part of it is the actual physical use of the wilderness and so it was my job to communicate that to the public.

DL: How, can you tell us a little bit about Reach a Teacher, Touch the World? Or did I get that?

CS: That’s right. Reach a Teacher, Touch the World.

DL: Because that’s pretty significant initiative that you had.

CS: Yes, it was really satisfying. When I worked in Iowa as a teacher there was a stint there that I worked for the Department of Education in Iowa as the assistant to the environmental education director for the state and we taught environmental education or conservation education, I like to call it conservation education, a better choice of words I think. But we taught to teachers and showed them how to teach children about conservation education. While I was in that job I wrote a grant proposal for taking teachers to the wilderness and they would do actual work projects, clearing trail, rehabbing camp sites, and the list goes on but they would actually do physical labor in the woods. And then they would write curriculum while they were camped out there, they would get ideas about how they would use wilderness education in their classrooms. So it ran the gamut of art teachers, PE teachers, whatever, and they would come up with ideas about implementing wilderness education and either then or when they got back to the classroom in Iowa they would write a lesson plan and they submitted it to me and then they would report every few weeks as to the progress and accomplishments and then they would receive also college credit from the University of Northern Iowa for education. So it was a great project. There were wonderful teachers who came out. There were wonderful ideas that implemented wilderness education.

DL: That’s amazing. Do you remember any of the projects that the teachers came up with to take back to the classrooms? Like do any stick out in particular as being?

CS: It’s been a long time ago. I remember an art teacher took photographs of the wilderness area and explained to her students what wilderness was and she had them create projects related to art. I remember a home ec teacher, she had her students make placemats that showed wilderness scenes and then she had projects in cooking, you know, with like back country cooking and whatever for her students.

DL: That’s awesome. So you, you were saying that you started out hiking alone and I know that you prefer that now. And some people might think a woman hiking alone how could you, like do you get frightened, how do you handle that? Not just as a woman but as a person just kind of the loneliness aspect of it?

CS: I’m a loner by nature although I do like people. I enjoy being with people. I like being by myself a lot. That’s very important to me and I don’t think loneliness was so much a factor. I would see people occasionally passing by and whatever. Sometimes I would go four or five days without seeing someone. But the fearfulness I don’t remember really being afraid of anything. I’m a spiritual and faithful person and I kind of gave over my life to, you know, there’s God taking care of me and I know that but I did learn to, and I don’t remember being fearful. There was lightening storms and there were creek crossings and there were lots of challenging things physically but I’m naturally an impatient person and this taught me, since I was by myself, to be very careful about where you put your feet, you know, Connie if you get hurt here there’s no way anybody’s going to help you, you’re on your own. So it taught me to plan ahead about how I would negotiate this or that or how I would deal with the water supply or bee stings and that kind of thing. I just love being in that place so much. It just took care of me, you know. It’s a pretty overpowering feeling to look up into those hills and especially being a flatlander like I was. I still am in awe of the power of those mountains and the power of the weather and the creeks and just the sheer hugeness of it and the fact that we’re not in control of anything.

DL: So you, even after you quit working officially for the Forest Service, you got right back involved in teaching and educating people how to work in the wilderness. Can you talk about what you do now with the interns and volunteers through the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation?

CS: I had to get back. I couldn’t leave. I guess it might have been selfish on my part but I really believed in the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation. It began to be formed just as I was starting to end my career there so it overlapped. The Selway-Bitterroot Foundation was just getting on its feet and really in its infancy and so we had several projects going on. I think people didn’t realize how many projects we had before it really came into being as it is now. But we had many, many projects. And I was the only field leader then so I was still really busy in the woods with different projects and that made me happy because I got to be there. And then I got to help train the wilderness interns when Rob Mason came on board and really transformed the Selway-Bitterroot Frank Church Foundation into the organization that it’s becoming. I helped in getting that part going and then I’m in a limited capacity now. There’ll be a group from Iowa coming in July and I’ll be with them but it’s still an opportunity to expose other people to the wilderness and, you know, it’s kind of an, education kind of takes care of itself. If you can get them there, if you can get people to the wilderness they become advocates already. They understand, they get it. If you just get the people to that place then the rest of the work is done for you. It’s, I don’t, maybe not work but the education is done for you. They get it.

title: Women in Wilderness
introduction: In this episode, titled “Women in Wilderness,” we hear from Rachel Kaufman, a third generation Montanan, who grew up enjoying the recreational opportunities that wilderness offers.  Rachel graduated from the University of Montana with a B. S. in Natural Resource Conservation, and she has previously worked as a wilderness ranger in Washington’s Alpine Lakes Wilderness and on wilderness trail crews in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness and the Chugach National Forest in Alaska. Rachel decided that she had seen a lot of beautiful places, but nothing was quite like the mountains of Montana.  She also felt a little bit of ownership, and felt that she needed to come back and be a part of the conservation effort.  In 2010, Rachel got a job with the Bitterroot National Forest on a trail crew, and then from there, she started working for the Selway-Bitterroot Frank Church Foundation during the summer season.  As the SBFCF’s web site comments, “Her lively personality and enthusiasm for wilderness stewardship compliment Rachel’s strong wilderness background to make her an effective and engaging wilderness leader. She is thankful for this opportunity to give back to the wild places that she loves and respects so much.”

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewee: Rachel Kaufman
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Missoula, Montana
Date: April 20, 2011

DL: That’s really cool. So, you wrote this article in, what was it?

RK: Oh, the Bitterroot Star.

DL: The Bitterroot Star. Can you talk about the event that caused this article?

RK: Yeah, so the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation and the Montana Wilderness Association kind of started this collaboration with the younger members of the Montana Wilderness Association called the Ridge Runners. The idea was to do five to six volunteer projects – day-long volunteer trips – throughout the summer. I had found the Blodgett Overlook Trail, which is this beautiful… it’s about a mile and a half long trail, and it goes up to overlook this iconic canyon in the Bitterroots, and there’s a beautiful overlook up to an arch…if you look south, there’s a natural rock arch, when you’re at the bridge, the stock bridge.

DL: Yes, I was at the stock bridge.

RK: Next time if you look south when you do it, there’s an archway. Okay, so anyway, this is a different trail from the canyon trail. My Montana… my Ridge Runner volunteers… it was two gals plus myself. We went up to this trail. It’s a very steep, switchbacking trail, and so trail users will often just cut off the switchbacks; they’ll often just go straight up the switchbacks, and that’s really detrimental to the soil and the ecology of that area. It creates… water runs off a lot more quickly, and there’s… the erosion is immense, especially on this trail. The erosion is immense, and the cutoffs between the switchbacks are five to fifteen feet in some places, because people are just going up and spreading their impact, and so it’s really a problem. From there, weeds can infest, it’s bare, compacted soil so native plants aren’t going to seed there as easily as non-native plants and invasive weeds will come in, so the three of us were on a mission to do… we installed some signs, some that said please stay off these trails, there’s restoration in progress, and then a couple more that kind of explained why you shouldn’t cut off switchbacks. Those reasons that I just explained about: the weeds and the erosion, etc. We installed three signs. It meant digging big holes, lugging up the lumber, that sort of thing. Then, we also dragged branches and tree stumps and rocks, and whatever we could, and we chunked up the cutoffs with pulaskis and shovels, and then blocked off these cutoffs with major scary-looking pieces of wood, so hopefully the idea is that people will stay on the trail. They won’t cut off those switchbacks, and I’m hoping that maybe actually in a couple of weeks to months I can go up and actually seed some native seeds up there. That was part of my… if we chunk up the soil, we can get rid of some of the compaction that has occurred, and maybe seedlings – native seedlings – will take place.

DL: Cool, cool. So what’s it like to do a project with all women, and no testosterone on the trail?

RK: It is really fun, actually. The two gals that I was working with really stepped up, and I think when there’s… when males aren’t involved, I think females step up a little bit more. I mean there’s always that strength and power there, but often the tendency or the habit to defer takes over, and without any males around, these two gals were hauling the biggest stumps around, and grunting and really feeling their female power. That’s so fun for me to see, because often it’s suppressed. This all-woman trio was great to work with.

DL: Ah, so can you think of an example when it was suppressed that maybe you observed, or that you actually experienced?

RK: Well, I know myself personally, I kind of… I’ve worked on all-male crews for a lot of years, and I’m torn in two different directions. In one way, I’m definitely working to prove myself, and often over-exerting myself, but on the other hand, I guess I feel compelled to admit the fact that I’m not as physically strong to everybody. That’s not necessarily that fun, but it’s also good to recognize, okay, well maybe I’m not as physically strong, but I know how to use teamwork and collaboration to accomplish the exact same thing, or my problem-solving skills might be more tuned because I can’t just use brute force, and that sort of thing.

DL: Have you met any women on the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness area that you maybe look up to as a role model?

RK: Definitely. Yeah, there’s… I worked with a gal with the Forest Service who –she was also on my crew – and she’d been doing trail crew type things for ten years, and she had an amazing eye for how to use a crosscut, and how to use the crosscut with the least amount of effort to make the most efficient cuts, and she knew so much about the trade, it was amazing. There were some other women on the national forest who were wilderness rangers, and the wilderness manager there, they’re all good horsemen, good backcountry stewards, awesome with teaching people how to do Leave No Trace, and that sort of thing, so I definitely have quite a few role models, well, I guess three or four.

DL: That’s cool. Now, you have taken a couple of solo trips, or? Can you talk about hiking solo, because I know some people are afraid to hike solo, especially women, so can you talk about one or two of those trips?

RK: Yeah, so I’ve done… this past fall, I was doing some work for the Forest Service, where they’d had a wilderness ranger who was gone, and he was… his workload needed to be done, so they asked me to do it, and so I did that through the Foundation, and it involved inspecting some outfitter camps. It was in the fall, and so these outfitters had set up their camps, and they need to follow certain regulations in the wilderness that have to do with impact, and usage, and that sort of thing. So there was a whole system of checking off if they’re doing the right sorts of things. This was actually in the Frank Church Wilderness, the River of No Return Wilderness. So, I was hiking maybe fifteen miles a day to get to these remote campsites, and I was doing it by myself, and it’s interesting. I’ve done some hiking by myself for shorter periods of time, but these were five to six days in some cases, which is really an interesting opportunity to be reflective. That’s one thing. I definitely do some things different when I’m backpacking by myself. One of those is that I bring a little mp3 player, because I am a little bit scared of the noises that go bump in the night. When I’m trying to fall asleep, earplugs don’t necessarily cut it, and so I’d like to listen to the music to help me fall asleep. In the past, I think like when I was 18 or 19, I would have completely pooh-poohed that idea. I would have been: you can’t bring something like that into the wilderness, or even into the outdoors, just enjoy the noises, but I’d had enough sleepless nights, that I was just kind of resigned to the mp3 player, and in fact, I discovered that it was sort of nice to hike to, actually. It had an external speaker, so I could, when I was feeling a little bit lonely, or had a song stuck in my head that I was tired of, because that happens when you’re by yourself, you just get one line over and over from the most annoying song you can imagine, and so, it served to eradicate the annoying song. I had some kind of creepy experiences. I was never really necessarily scared. You get into your routines when you’re by yourself, which is very interesting. You kind of have to remember to take time, and not do it all at once, because it’s very easy to get done hiking, cook your dinner, and then crawl into bed. But then you’re in bed at 4:00, or 5:30 or whatever. 6:00 maybe. So, I really enjoyed finding ways to not rush through the things that you’re used to doing, like cooking, and setting up your tent and going to bed. I took a lot of walks in kind of the evening time. When you’re with someone, you might be sitting around the campfire, or you might be socializing someway. In this case, I was kind of exploring the campsite a little bit more. That evening, I awoke to a tree falling. I awoke to the crash of a tree falling. So, that was… I always, when I’m setting up a camp, look, because I’ve mentioned before, I’ve had a tree fall in the middle of the campsite before. That was another moment where you’re like Holy Crap, but you can’t really say it to anyone, so you just lay awake instead.

DL: When you made your solo trip to Tin Cup and Kerlee, you encountered a cabin, or not? What happened there?

RK: Right, so this was a campsite monitoring trip that I went on, and I take photocopies of past inventories that wilderness rangers have made from the seventies on, to kind of help me as a rubric. Well, what was it… what did it look like five years ago? The campsites are supposed to be monitored every five years. What am I looking for, what landmarks am I looking for, how do I find this campsite, and then, I’ll make a little map of it, and so one of the campsites that I was looking for, the inventory described it as being a ways off the trail, following a little social trail, and there would be the remains of a cabin there. Or there was a cabin there, I think is what it said, something along those lines. I just spent a ton of time looking for it. I really wanted to see this old cabin, and I never found it. I didn’t find a trail; I didn’t find the remains… nothing like that. But I got back, and I talked to the wilderness ranger who’d actually written up this old inventory, and she said, well, you know this cabin actually was built by the Kerlee family. The Kerlee family is… I mean this is Kerlee Creek, Kerlee Lake, and now there’s this… I didn’t know that there was a Kerlee family who had a cabin, and so that was very interesting. She said up until around 10 or 15 years ago, the cabin was being used by the Kerlee family, and at some point that use came to an end. She and her co-worker went and dismantled and burned the cabin. So, this was just an example of how recent history can be. I was actually pretty disappointed that I hadn’t been able to find the remains of the cabin, and see what someone had built back in the forest. But very interesting. She also told me that the Kerlee family still lives in the valley. Are still alive. So it’s living history.

DL: Yes! That’s right.

RK: It’s very cool. History can be last year, even. It still has that impact on you.

DL: Yeah, that’s right.

title: Wilderness Photography
introduction: In this episode, titled “Wilderness Photography,” Dick Walker shares some personal experiences with this watershed, and the fish and wildlife of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. Dick began as a wilderness ranger on the Moose Creek Ranger District, starting in 1969. While there, he began applying the results he gained from his Master’s thesis “Photography as an Aid to Wilderness Resource Inventory and Analysis”. During the past 40 years, Dick continued incorporating both aerial and terrestrial photography to capture the seasonal moments: from winter ski trips, to all season backpack and private float trips, always searching for the historical connection, documenting Nature’s ever-changing wilderness ecosystems, as well as identifying misuse or overuse of the Wilderness Resource. Dick has also turned many of his stunning backcountry photos into an art that brings forth the sustainable fragile beauty of the untrammeled wilderness. In addition to serving as a Wilderness Resource Assistant, Dick was a Wilderness Planner and Team Leader on a Congressional Wilderness Study. He’s also a backcountry pilot and is still flying fire patrol, as well as promoting wilderness values while living sustainably.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Interviewee: Dick Walker
Location: Moscow, Idaho
Date: March 7, 2011
Topic: Wilderness Photography

DL: Could you talk a little bit about how you got interested in photographing images and turning them into artwork?

DW: I think at first, it was the objective was to document. And it was a little later, I remember going to a… taking leave and going to an Ansel Adams presentation at WSU. I remember, I got there early, and it was in one of the auditoriums, and Ansel came in, and sat down midway down on the left side, and I went up and introduced myself, and when I reached out to shake his hand, he withdrew his hand, and he said, gently. Man, he said, I’ve got arthritis. It wasn’t until just recently that I understood what the hell he was talking about. Because I’m starting to get that affliction myself. So I… but anyway, that was my first… I never got to attend one of his workshops. This was as close as I got. It was at that point… he was using a 35mm KodaChromes for his presentation. And, you know all of his primary work was 8×10 format negative camera, black and white, primarily. He did some Polaroid work, later on. I guess maybe that’s where it first… Like Wallace Stegner… you were doing more than documenting. You were trying to capture a sense of place. Which Ansel did very well. So did so many of those early photographers, with the F64 Club, or whatever, where they were shooting for maximum depth-of-field. But anyway, that’s…

DL: There’s one photo in particular, a set of photos, “A Remnant of What Once Was,” and I know that they took place in 2001, and they’re based on an experience you had with Sarah Walker. Can you just tell us about that experience, and how you happened upon that scene, and kind of tell the story of that?

DW: There were a number of sequences, but I think the one that you’re referring to was… Early that spring…

DL: What spring? 2001?

DW: 2001. There was a tremendous, totally abnormal, in contemporary terms, flush of spring Chinook salmon. Coming up the Snake and in the Clearwater, and that was the first spring Chinook salmon I had ever caught. I was with Steve Pettit, a close friend. We caught these spring Chinook, and of course, you could keep them, and these were hatchery fish; they did not have the adipose. Then, later that year, Sarah and I flew in, and we were on up this major drainage that flows into the Selway, and I had first been on that drainage the fall of 1969, and I was heading up toward the Montana border, and I’d seen this set of pools. I even took a photograph or two, and it was a beautiful place, pictorially, but when Sarah and I were up there, the place was filled with these giant spring Chinook salmon. Now, these are salmon that are like, 2 ½ to almost 4 feet long. I mean they all had their adipose fin. These were wild. These were a remnant, truly, of what once was, and this is probably the most intact hydrologic watershed left in the, at least the anadromous fisheries part of the Pacific Northwest. So, it’s not a question of will the habitat support the fish; it’s the friggin’ dams that are screwing up the fish. It’s not the habitat, the lack of habitat. There was one fish that I called Whitey; there’s… I don’t know the correct terminology, Steve can clarify that, but when the fish are going downstream in the spring of the year, when they go over the dams, they get something called nitrogen fixation, or something. They’re affected at that point in time, but it doesn’t raise hell with them until two or three or four years later, when they head back up into the fresh water. When they first enter the fresh water, then they start losing big patches of skin, and stuff. Whitey had lost all of the skin and the eyes on his head, and how in the hell that fish got all the way up through all those major rapids, including Selway Falls, and then all the way up the Selway… I mean it did it by scent, and something that… hell, we can’t even relate to. But it made it there. I have close-up photos of that, because it couldn’t see me, and I’ve got photos where it was only six feet away, where it was swimming totally oblivious to me, but it knew… it was waiting.

DL: I know that you have a tremendous collection of historical papers and photographs. How did you get interested in the history of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, and are there any historical stories that particularly stick with you as being really important?

DW: I guess, initially, the history of the place didn’t have very much import or meaning to me. I was more interested in the physicality of it. My comparison was with the Rawah, which I had only made a fall trip into. In the Mount Zirkel Wilderness, there were a number of old mining claims and stuff, so, you know that… you couldn’t go buy an old mine and not realize that something had gone on there. Well, in the Selway, you didn’t have those kinds of physical impacts, and two years before I came in, the forest Service had purchased a… what was called at that time, Moose Creek Ranches. It was a complex of, I believe, about seven homesteads up there. Anyway, the structures that were on those places either had been burned incidentally or on purpose. All except for a few that weren’t right in your face, so to speak. Either the Forest Service people didn’t know they were there, or they didn’t pose that much of an assumed dilemma with the wilderness resource. Anyway, the more field trips I went on, the more I began seeing blazes that were not Forest Service, not the heel-toe Forest Service blaze. These blazes might be, rather than four or five feet above ground level, they might be ten or maybe fifteen feet up above ground level, and there’d be these notches cut in the trees, and if the tree was a green tree, this… what had been a layer, a martin set cut in with a notch, so it was like an undercut on a tree you were getting ready to fell, or fall, the top of the arch on a green tree, it sort of rounded over, so it looked like a cathedral arch, and I was wondering what in the hell are these cathedral arches? I’d follow this… so I’d get off the Forest Service trail, and I’d be following… most of these were along a ridgeline. Then they’d drop down so… and usually where they’d drop down you’d find either a cabin, or the remnants of a cabin. So these were the old trap lines, and stuff. So, that was my first… that was my teaser. I began looking more, and more, and more. I remember my first encounter with Jimmy Renshaw. I had come up from Barren Hill, and was walking up Wounded Doe Ridge, and of course the trail then, it was not a mainline trail. In fact, some places, when you’re going through the… hell, I can’t remember what… the ferns. The bracken fern. Big, heavy feel. You could feel the trail with your feet. You couldn’t see it, because the bracken fern was so frigging thick. So you’d go along the trails, feeling the tread with your feet. Anyway, I was around Tribulation Saddle, some place like that, and I saw some stock, and I went down and traced down the brand, and so on, and a couple of days later, when I got to Fish Lake, and I was going up behind Fish Lake, well, I came on to this camp, and this Jimmy Renshaw fellow was there. He mentioned… I remember him saying something like that… well, I wondered whose man-sign I saw. So, I knew I was talking to somebody who had his feet on the ground, and his eyes open. Jimmy was the first person that told me about the possibility of Hudson Bay Cabin being downstream and above the meadow complex at Fish Lake, there. I remember seeing the trail and this cabin early on, and it had a stone fireplace in it, so I knew it was an old, old cabin. There was another cabin that was down on the… below the trail toward the meadow complex, there. It had a puncheon roof, and you could see along the edge where they had dug out the earth right along the edge of the cabin and covered the roof for insulation. Of course that made it so that the roof was one of the first things to rot on this cabin as the years… I took some core samples of the Lodgepole Pine right there, and I don’t remember, they were around fifty years old or so, so anyway that cabin was somewhere between sixty-five, seventy years old or older.

DL: And this was in 19-?

DW: That would have been probably ’70. ’69 or ’70 would be my guess. Somebody like Jim knew the country. Or somebody like Arnold Oswald, or Punk Wolfinbarger, those individuals knew segments of that country much deeper than any of the rest of us will ever know.

title: Appreciating and Protecting the Resource That Is Wilderness
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Appreciating and Protecting the Resource That Is Wilderness,” we hear from Ed Bloedel, who was instrumental in helping to write the first management plans for the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, thus implementing the Wilderness Act of 1964 in a tangible, practical way.

Ed holds a degree from the University of Montana in Range Management Forestry, and started out as a forester in the Beaverhead Forest in southwestern Montana; from there he worked as District Ranger on both the Custer and the Gallatin Forests in Montana. His work with the Regional Wilderness Staff in writing Wilderness Act Guidelines then led him to the Bitterroot Forest as Wilderness Staff Officer. He was later promoted to Regional Wilderness and Wild River Staff Officer in the Southern Region, Atlanta, Georgia, where he led numerous Wilderness, Wild River, and Trail Training sessions. He eventually served as the Director of Wilderness for the entire United States, based in Washington DC, where he spread the Wilderness Act’s Philosophy of wilderness as a natural resource to areas all over the country.

Because of his experience as a smoke jumper, a river runner, and his knowledge of recreational and resource management, Ed joined and led teams in crafting the first wilderness management plans for wild river use, natural fire use and wilderness resource management in the Selway-Bitterroot that set the standard for wilderness management all over the United States. Today, Ed is still active in helping to raise awareness of wilderness issues, and write bills that further wilderness preservation. Ed lives on the edge of the Bitterroot Mountains where he plays his fiddle in the style of the original settlers who called the Selway-Bitterroot home.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip
Interview with: Ed Bloedel
Interviewers: Debbie Lee
Location: Corvallis, Montana (right outside of Hamilton)
Date: April 18, 2011
TOPIC: Implementation of the Wilderness Act of 1964

EB: …The wilderness, of course, had been established for a long time, but they never really had a specific plan of how we were going to try to manage it. It was after a Region 1 workshop that told us… that we sat together and worked, instructed by Bill Warf as the recreation staff officer, and others what wilderness was like, and what it was about, and then our studies. We said well, it’s time we should put together a plan for this. There was overuse up around Big Creek Lake, up around the popular lakes back in here on the west side, coming out of Hamilton, so it was time to figure out what to do. So we began to prepare a plan. In those days, we thought it would be a good idea if we involved the people, because there was a lot of people interested in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. Outfitters, and besides them a lot of individuals that live here in the valley, or that come from all over Montana just to work their way back in there. So, we had a list of, I don’t know, 2-300 different people and agencies and all the county officers and the state officers, and even the congressional delegation. Max Baucus was on board then, too. He was kind of a young senator then. It was in 1975. ’74 and ’75 when we were working on that. He’s still a senator. So we started to write the plan, and by gathering the people together, and telling what some of the problems were, and what the situation was, and how… and then asking, how do you think we should manage this area and still keep it as wild as possible? So we set up little tables and had group discussion, and then they’d bring back their report, and we’d put those reports together, and we had help, of course, with the coordinating people that know how to do that sort of thing. Then we prepared the plan, and finally put it in place.

DL: So do you remember any specific struggles or controversies or “aha” moments that happened during that process?

EB: Yeah, let me give you a specific… Two ladies – two of my favorite ladies here; I think they may have passed now – in the Bitterroot, wrote me a letter one time during the process. It was just after or just before, I can’t remember, we made the plan. Said they were walking up Sawtooth Creek and the log was gone that they normally cross. So they had to cross the stream early in the spring. They didn’t make it. They fell down, and they got wet, and they wrote me… it’s hilarious little story about how in the wilderness, couldn’t you at least replace a log, you know, as a bridge. They wrote it to the Forest Service, and of course the wilderness staff officer gets to answer for the Forest Supervisor, write his letter back. So I wrote them one back, and told them how wonderful a wilderness experience they had, and I don’t think we will be replacing that bridge. It should stay wild. We had a good conversation after that. Eventually, we put another log across there, a single log bridge, because in the spring time, the water is so swift, it’s very difficult to get across.

DL: That’s a great story. So, that must have involved a lot of different people’s idea about what wilderness was, especially so soon after the Wilderness Act was passed.

EB: Oh, I’ll say.

DL: How did you navigate that, and how has your own definition of wilderness changed through that process and through the years?

EB: It never changed, except to get stronger through the years. You see, my career after here, I went to the Region 8 and I was the wilderness and trails and river specialist there for that whole region: southeast region. Then I went from there into Washington offices, the wilderness specialist for the chief. In those days, I began to… before I went there, though, I had the philosophy of what wilderness was about based on the law. By taking the law itself, where it says specifically, this is what wilderness is, it’s defined, it starts right out in the first… right under the preamble. In order to prevent all of this development, and everything being developed, where Congress established an enduring resource of wilderness. And right from there, “an enduring resource of wilderness” set up the philosophy. The philosophy is that wilderness is a resource in itself, and it’s defined by the parts of the wilderness act that say there’ll be no buildings, no roads, the least amount of civilization as possible, natural conditions will continue to take place. Other things can take place in wilderness, like recreation use, fishing and hunting, but the primary purpose is to preserve the wilderness as a resource, and it stays wild. Always. So that philosophy was crammed… was jammed into me from Bill Warf and some others that were leaders in Region 1 at the time. Region 1 put together the first workshop for all us… in fact, I have to back up a little bit, here. I got that philosophy earlier than before I started working here, on the Selway-Bitterroot. I was a ranger at the time we developed this philosophy in Region 1 over on the Gallatin on the Gallatin Ranger District. It’s now combined into two ranger districts. At that time it was called Squaw Creek ranger district. The Spanish Peaks wilderness was on our district. We had a workshop here, when I was there in 1966-1972, sometime during that period was when the region had its first workshop in how to manage wilderness and how to put together this philosophy as to how… as to making it a basic resource, and a wild resource, and keeping it that way. So I was all worked up with that, by the time I got the job over here. I’d gone through a range job and the regional office, and a job out here. In fact, we had, when I was there in that ranger district, all the rangers in Region 1 that had wilderness, and all the resource assistants that had wilderness, and a lot of the wilderness rangers that were operating, still working during that period of time when we had that spring workshop, like Dick Walker, and others that have been a long time with us. That’s where I developed the philosophy and strength and the understanding of the wilderness resource, and it’s all based on the Act, and it’s based on a strict interpretation of the Act, instead of looking in the Act for where the exceptions are, and what you might get away with, and how you can manage it, you look for how you can keep it as wild as possible. When you have that philosophy, there’s no problem in working with some of the exceptions if you have, to, but the basic philosophy is the protection of the wilderness resource, and keeping it intact. So, I had that, and so I brought that over here when I came. I started to say, about that time, we were also having… we had fifteen, or eighteen I guess, new outfitter applications to float the wild Selway River. So, we sat down with the Moose Creek district ranger and the recreation staff officer over there on the Nez Perce, because the river’s both on the Bitterroot Forest and on the Nez Perce. We sat down together and we said, we gotta do something about this. Of course, by that time, I’d floated the river a couple of times, and I understood how wild it was. The ranger, Dean Burn at the West Fork, and myself, and these resource assistants said, all of these guys are applying, but they’re not here yet. There’s four of them that are here now. Let’s leave it at four. Let’s start with that. Let’s allow the public to start building their own use, without having to come through an outfitter. So we set four… we established in the plan the four outfitters, and their four… I think it was four launches apiece throughout the very short season in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness—in the Selway River. The rest of the days, which was the majority of them, to be open for drawing to float the river. Well, we had a massive amount of applications for the drawing, even right from the start. You know, the philosophy of outfitting guiding is: outfit and guides are there to help people be able to use wilderness or enjoy the wilderness of enjoy some other countryside, hunting, whatever. When there’s not enough people already getting there, or when it’s too difficult for them, long distances, or too much equipment, you can’t afford all the equipment, and all that sort of thing. Well, there was plenty of people that could afford the equipment and wanted to float the river, so we felt that we’d have a river… As long as there was a river there with all those other people, thousands of people floating… As long as there was a river in the National Park service with motorboats floating down through the Grand Canyon; we talked to those people. We did talk to different people when we were writing this plan, and the difficulty they were having in trying to reduce the amount of use, and the noise with the motor boats and other stuff in their wilderness, in the Grand Canyon… Why not create a wilderness river that’s really a wilderness river? We’d just have one launch a day, let the people camp wherever they want, let them stay as long as they want, but not let it get crowded. And that was our philosophy, and that’s why we wrote that plan as strictly as we did.

[sample of Ed playing his fiddle]

EB: Red-wing. Old timey song.

title: “It’s So Wild”
introduction: One of the unique features of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness is the way people who manage it have preserved the wilderness character, and how they have taught others to cherish wild land as a valuable natural resource. In this episode, titled “’It’s So Wild,’” Rob Mason compares his experience working in many of the national forests throughout the western United States with his work for the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. Since December 2008, Rob has served as the executive director of the Selway-Bitterroot Frank Church Foundation, whose mission is to connect citizens and communities to assist in the stewardship of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, and the surrounding wildlands. Prior to joining the Foundation, Rob worked as the wilderness manager for the Sierra National Forest for five years, where he earned the Forest Service’s Bob Marshall Award for Individual Champion of Wilderness Stewardship for his work in the John Muir and Ansel Adams Wildernesses. In his work and life, Rob consistently shows a deep passion for wilderness stewardship and protecting wilderness character.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Clip

Interview with: Rob Mason
Interviewers: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: Moscow Idaho
Date: March 5, 2011

RM: So, eventually I did apply for the position and I was lucky enough to get to work for the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation, and that’s how I got up here in the nonprofit sector working in the Selway.

DL: So when you say take care of the places what does that mean?

RM: Well, the Wilderness Act defines sort of broadly what it means to steward a wilderness area, and basically what it says is to protect wilderness character… the number one job of all the agencies when it comes to wilderness is to protect wilderness character. So, it’s kind of a vague term, “wilderness character.” It’s been defined by agencies, but in general you can say it means do it whatever you need to do to make sure this place stays wild, natural, undeveloped, untrammeled… has solitude and those kind of qualities. So that’s kind of what to me taking care of a place means. Protecting the wilderness character of it. And how that plays out in the field is in any number of ways. Of course things as basic as opening trails, to invasive weed management, recreation management, regulations to protect solitude if necessary.

DL: So what are some of the… Do you have any experiences of experiencing solitude in the wilderness that particularly inform your idea about it?

RM: Solitude is probably the one of the trickiest things to try to manage for in the wilderness, because it’s so because it means so many different things to so many different people. When I worked in the Sierras, if you only saw 20 people in a day, that was solitude to me, because it was so crowded there. For someone coming up from LA, if they were camped at a lake with 100 people, that was solitude because it was so remote compared to where they live. Up here, if you see two people in a day, you’re like, wow, that was amazing. We got to talk to some people today besides our crew. And usually, that’s not what happens. Usually, you don’t see anyone a lot of times, besides your crew. So it’s a tricky thing… it’s a social science really, solitude is. I am not a social scientist. But that’s a hard one to define. For me, with the background that I have…

DL: And you personally. Can you… if someone said, well, give me an example of when you personally experienced it, what would be your example?

RM: Well, I’ve been lucky enough to be in a lot of wilderness areas in my life. I will say that the Selway is unquestionably the wildest place, and part of that is because of the tremendous solitude. For me, part of solitude is also… I experience it most intensely when there’s also sort of a fear factor I guess would be the right word? When you don’t really know what the outcome’s going to be. There is a risk you’re taking and you’re by yourself. I have really never experienced that as intensely anywhere else as I have in the Selway because you’re so far away from anything when you’re solo backpacking through the Selway, and if you don’t have a radio with you, which often times you don’t necessarily if you’re a member of the public, and even if we’re not on work time. You experience it to a high degree.

DL: So, when you first came into the wilderness, you say you’ve been a lot of wilderness areas, you’ve been lucky enough… When you first came into the Selway-Bitterroot country, what was different about the place, I mean obviously you said the remoteness and the lack of people, but is there anything peculiar or odd or… that struck you?

RM: The thing that makes the Selway special is it… I guess I didn’t realize this to the full extent that I feel like I do now when I came here, but it is super wild. I mean it is what wilderness… the epitome of wilderness to me. A wildness, I guess, and it’s because it’s so big and there are so few intrusions from the outside so… and contrast a place like Death Valley which is a lot of wilderness has a lot of roads cutting up into it.. I mean cherry stemming into the wilderness boundaries. The Selway doesn’t, and so it’s this big contiguous block, and also the populations around it are low, and so you don’t get that many people there, and it’s so rugged I mean it’s unquestionably the most rugged place I’ve ever been. I mean more rugged than the Olympic peninsula to me, far more rugged than the Sierras or the Southern Rockies, and that makes it hard to get around, so all of that collectively makes it incredibly wild, and that’s what really strikes me about the Selway. It’s not spectacular scenery, although it is beautiful, but it is wild.

DL: Right, and it has to grow on you.

RM: Right.

DL: Yeah. So what… can you tell us about one of your most… maybe one trip in particular that was memorable to you?

RM: I decided one day to hike in to Moose Creek in a day from Paradise. This was in my off time; I just wanted to go visit some folks at Moose Creek, and I decided… I knew there were some beds back there, and I think I had left a sleeping bag there and a tent, so I didn’t really need overnight stuff. So I was like, all right. I’m just going to move light and fast. I’m going to wear tennis shoes. I’m going to take a little day pack and I’m just going to go. Thirty miles or something like that. Well, that part of the Selway trail is way more rocky than the downstream part of the Selway trail, below Moose Creek. It was a huge mistake. By about halfway through, you know, a thirty mile hike is never easy no matter where you are, even if it’s flat dirt. But my feet were just in horrible pain. I felt like I could barely walk. I tried to stop in at Selway Lodge for a break and no one was there, so I just kept moving through. But I didn’t have any stuff to… I couldn’t stop. Because I didn’t have any stuff with me. I mean I would have had to basically cover myself in leaves if I wanted to spend the night somewhere. I had no food. I mean I had some snacks, but it was just horrible. I couldn’t really walk the next day, both from blisters, and from, just fatigue. That was one of the memorable trips. I’ll never do that again.

DL: Okay. So, what do you see in terms of wilderness and the wilderness preservation system throughout North America and why is the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness important in the larger system in terms of the country, and maybe even the world?

RM: The Selway is the third largest wilderness area today in the lower 48 states. It’s right adjacent to the Frank, which you could argue is the first or second largest wilderness area, depending how people define Death Valley, which would rival it. I guess the Selway is a flagship in the National Wilderness Preservation System because of its size and its complexity. It sets a lot of examples of what should happen in a lot of other places around the country. For example, wildfire policy, or wilderness wildfire policy. The Selway was sort of the testing grounds, and it could be the testing grounds because it was so big and remote, and you could let a fire rip and it wasn’t going to burn down a community somewhere. I guess on a broader sense, I think the Selway is important for the country because it says something when a country says, we’re going to set aside a chunk of land, and a huge chunk of land that actually does have a lot of resources that could be used for human uses, extractive uses, but we’re not going to do that. We’re going to set it aside for all of the values we know wilderness has. That’s powerful, and I think it opens the door for allowing that to happen in other places, both in this country and in other countries, really. So to me, the Selway is incredibly valuable for those two reasons, and I’m sure we could list a million others.

title: Whitewater on the Selway River
introduction: The Selway River runs all the way through the wilderness and is one of the area’s main attractions. Technically difficult, with a limited launch season, the Selway is the most coveted wild river to run in the lower 48 states. In this episode, titled “Whitewater on the Selway River,” we meet Jerry Hughes, the owner of Hughes River Expeditions, who has worked as a river guide since 1966 and an outfitter since 1976. From an early age, Jerry knew he wanted to work on Idaho’s rivers. While in college, he rowed for Hatch River Expeditions, where he helped pioneer the early Selway river trips, just after the passage of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Later, he and his wife, Carole Finley, started their own river business, taking guests down some of the most exciting rivers in the northwestern United States. Listen as Jerry tells stories of working as a boatman and guide on some of the earliest outfitter trips down the Selway River.
