Audio Clip

Interview with: Jerry Hughes
Interviewers: Debbie Lee and Jane Holman
Location: Cambridge, Idaho
Date: March 22, 2011
TOPIC: Whitewater on the Selway River

DL: Okay Jerry, so, tell us a little bit about your background, and then maybe go to how you got connected with the Selway River.

JH: Sure. I was born in 1947, in southern Idaho. My family extended family were farm families, and my mother was a school teacher my dad worked in agriculture, and I was raised in Hazelton, Idaho. As a young kid I was watching a TV show that showed Don Smith riding a raft down the Middle Fork. I announced to my mother and my big sister, Roberta, that I was going to do that. Roberta, of course, laughed at me and made fun of me and we got in a fight. The summer of ’67, I got a job guiding for Hatch River Expeditions. That’s the summer that Bus Hatch passed away and his sons Don and Ted took over the business. I worked for Don and Ted for seven summers from 1967 through ‘73 while I was going to college and law school at University of Idaho. The way I got up to the Selway was kind of blind luck. ‘67 was the first year the Hatch, or really any of the river companies actually showed up and took people down the Selway River. The Hatch boats were old military surplus 10-mans. So down the river we went on extraordinarily low water. I never ran the Selway lower in the years that I worked there, than on that first trip. We had seven days, because Don wanted to make sure we could make our way down the river slowly, and scout, and take our time. I remember really having to push the boats until we made it down through the first couple of days. We were stuck in the rocks almost constantly, but we had a great trip. Some of my memories of that trip were: I’d never seen rattlesnakes that short and that fat, and they were everywhere it seems like especially on the upper river. That was the first time I’ve ever personally guided with Don, and Don and I really hit it off, and we became great friends. I got to boat several times with Don on the Selway in later years. We finished the trip up, and Don just felt like he had gone to heaven. He loved the Selway. He’d always been a Middle Fork guy. He loved the Middle Fork, and he loved the Green River and Lodore, kind of small rocky rivers. But the Selway instantly became his favorite river. It was neat to go with Don Hatch, because the guy was undoubtedly the best boatman I ever followed in my life. Don would just sit on his boat and it would go where it was supposed to go without any oar strokes, and the rest of us would be following along behind him, rowing back and forth, and spinning around, and doing spins. Don Hatch was just such a gentleman. He always was so proper. He always combed his hair, and he wore an Oxford button down shirt with Levi blue jeans and high top Chuck Taylors and was just quite a gentleman, and he loved to camp cook I got to really kind of learn how to be a river camp cook working with Don on those early trips.

DL: So how was the Selway… you said that Don Hatch… that was his favorite river. How was the Selway different from some of the other rivers you’ve run?

JH: I’m sure the reason Don liked it was: it’s very technically difficult. On the flows that we used to run. We you always used to run medium water down through medium-low water. That water condition on the Selway means it’s a Boatman’s river. You’re dodging around, and having to make tight fits through rocks, and there’s a steep gradient, so you always have something going on. You don’t just sit on the boats and cruise through flat water; you’re always busy. The rapids… the other fun thing is the rapids really change. They’re extremely tight and technical on the upper end of the river, and then by the time you’re down below Moose Creek, you’ve got enough volume that you’re starting to get some real punch to the river, from increased volume. It’s the style of river that Idaho boatmen absolutely love. It’s busy and tricky all the way. Also, Don loved the cool weather. He loved pine trees. He loved the crystal-clear water. I think probably the signature deal of the Middle Fork and the Selway has to be that crystal-clear water, which you don’t find anywhere else, that I know of in the boating world. The Selway and the Middle Fork of the Salmon are just extraordinary for that. We would come back and run the Selway once or twice, occasionally three times a summer during the rest of the years that I was there with Hatch. During the seven years I worked for Hatch, I think we missed one or two years due to high water or no reservations, but I managed to do the first nine trips that Hatch did on the Selway during those seven years. I just loved it… well, Wolf Creek was the most dramatic drop by far, and then probably most difficult rapid would be Osprey and Ladle. I’ve never been in there on high water because Don was so cautious about high water in the days that I worked for him. So, I’ve never seen Moose Juice where it really takes off, and you get all the flow out of Moose Creek, but my friends like Mel and Larry, and the guys that worked for Don; they gradually boated higher and higher water. They were able to deal with it. But I guess that thing becomes almost a continuous class four plus rapid, as the water goes up double drop, and Ladle, Little Niagara, all that stuff, and they just run together and so it must be really impressive. I have not seen it on the higher flows. I only ran relatively modest flows. In fact one of the fun little water stories about working for Don, was my last year: ’73, which was a low-water year across Idaho. We had three Selway trips planned. I got to go on all three; but the last trip that I went on the Selway when I guided for Don was ’73, and we flew into the Running Creek Ranch to launch. Which is kind of a fun little twist, and I think I’ve understood that they decided they didn’t want that air traffic, and so they didn’t do that often if at all in the future after that. The Selway was just so extraordinary. We were just so excited to have the opportunity to boat it. We realized that hardly anybody was getting to boat it. Yet, looking back on it, even though we valued that time on the river so much, I don’t think we probably even properly valued the fact that we were there really early on, and that we got the chance to do what we did. One of the interesting things I remember is, river camping was so primitive in those days. Of course, people just went out and went to the bathroom anywhere they could, and we had a shovel and you were supposed to cover things up, but we used to bury our garbage. Then we’d come back to the camp the next week or the next year, and all the garbage would be dug up, of course. A bear would have gotten into it. We were really surprised at that. We thought, oh, wonder why that happened. Talk about not thinking ahead. Within those early years, working in Idaho, the Forest Service, especially on the Middle Fork, told us, hey, it’s time to start carrying out garbage, and I think all the river guides’ reaction was, we can’t possibly do that. Well, now, of course, we’re not only carrying out garbage, but we’re usually using fire pans and carry-out toilets, and the river thing has changed so dramatically. The river camps are so much better for it. Those early days were kind of interesting.

title: Communities of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, part 2
introduction: In this episode, titled “Communities of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, part 2,” we hear from Eric Melson, who is a graduate of Colorado State University, where he earned a Bachelor of Science in Protected Area Management and developed a deep passion for wilderness stewardship, a love of wilderness travel, and a strong work ethic. During the fall of 2010, Eric became a full-time staff member of the Selway-Bitterroot Frank Church Foundation, a wilderness stewardship organization. He now leads the Selway-Bitterroot Frank Church Foundation’s work bringing the Telluride Mountain Film Festival to western Montana and Idaho as well as leads volunteer trail crews and trains interns in wilderness leadership skills during the summer months.

Audio Excerpt:

Interview with: Eric Melson
Interviewer: Debbie Lee
Location: Moscow, Idaho
Date: March 5, 2011
TOPIC: Communities of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, part 2

EM: For someone like me, I have fun doing anything, like cutting a tree is fun for me, you know.

DL: So why is cutting a tree fun for you?

EM: Because it’s a challenge. Because it’s a small puzzle. You’re using these “primitive” as they call them, as they’ve classified them, tools, and you’re using manual labor in a non-mechanical way, to remove these trees that weigh X amount of pounds, I mean hundreds and hundreds of pounds. If you don’t do something right, you have the risk of serious injury. You have the risk of damaging a priceless tool. You have the risk of damaging the trail even further, of creating more degradation to the trail. So it’s all – the whole thing – when you come up on a tree, and realize, thinking through what’s going to happen, looking through it as a… analyzing it critically and where you’re going to put your cuts, the most efficient way of getting that tree off of there. If it’s a big tree, you know, putting rollers underneath it or doing something that makes it just a little bit easier. Just the whole essence of trail clearing and crosscutting trees, I love it. It’s great.

DL: You’ve met some interesting people on the trail, and I know you helped in the rescue of a missing person. Do you want to tell us about that?

EM: Yeah. It was my intern year and we had just got finished with our wilderness training. Our field training with Rob. We had taken time off. We were in Moose Creek for a full hitch doing trail clearing techniques and talking about the management plan and the opportunity classes, the administrative side… the whole nine yards of the in-depth field learning aspect. We were just leaving – it was the first day – we were leaving Moose Creek with a full trail crew. We had seven, eight… eight or nine people? I think three or four crosscut saws, full trail-opening kits. People have shovels and axes and Pulaskis and picks hanging off their backpacks. We’re fully loaded, we’re going out, we’re doing fifteen miles that day, going up East Moose, up the 421 trail. We’re going to go camp at Elbow Bend. And the goal was to cut out the East Fork of Moose Creek all the way to the Clearwater boundary. So we’re on the move and we’re only, maybe, four or five miles from the ranger station at Moose Creek, going up the 421 East Moose trail. We’re in the Three Forks area, previously known as the Moose Ranches area. We’re in the meadow, and we’re going up towards that outfitter camp there, and there’s a gentleman on the trail heading south toward Moose Creek. He has a fishing pole and a walking stick and he’s wearing army fatigue rain gear. Here I am, I’m in the front of the pack and I’m like, hey what’s going on, how’s the fishing? I see his fishing pole and He says, yeah, well, I haven’t been able to catch anything, so I’ve been eating bugs and berries for the last eight days, and he asks us how far is a road? And here we are in the heart of a 1.3 million acre wilderness area and we are right in the center of it. And we think he’s kind of joking and we’re like, you know, the closest road is probably thirty miles from here and he just gives like a solemn nod, okay. And he plans on keep going. We stopped and he said well, what’s up with all the planes flying overhead and we were like, oh, well, there’s a ranger station, and he was like thank God. Like, I’ve made it. Now we start questioning him and we’re like what has been going on and he tells us that he’s been – that he got turned around up at Diablo Peak up in the Elk Summit area. He went in Elk Summit and he had enough food for two days. He was backpacking; he was on a short weekend trip. He had enough food for two days; he had a backpack with him at that time but decided that after he got turned around and lost the trail that the backpack was too heavy. So he dumped his backpack in the woods and kept like only the essentials. So that’s why he only had a tarp, a sleeping bag and a rope. And a fishing pole. He’d kept the fishing pole thinking he could fend for himself. We saw him on Day 10. So he had been going for eight days without a backpack, lost in the middle of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. And, he did the right thing which was to walk downstream in a large drainage, and eventually you’re going to hit a larger stream and follow that out. And he was on his way down to Moose Creek, so we had an EMT that was on the crew and the crew leader at that time decided that they needed to get this guy back to the ranger station and the permanent Wilderness Ranger back at Moose Creek was out on a hitch. She had just left that morning as well, so she was out the same distance we were in the opposite direction; she was going up Moose Ridge. We got her on the radio and they decided to meet back up at the rangersStation. So the EMT and Ian walked this gentleman back down to Moose Creek after we had given him some food. We gave him an orange and he ate it like an apple, peel and everything. Just bit right into it. Didn’t care that there was a peel on it, just ate the entire thing. They got him back to Moose Creek, called the LEO and sure enough, he was a missing person. He was a tourist, and he wanted to stop in the Selway to do a quick overnight, and he got turned around. He lost the trail in the snow and, you know, that’s what happens in wilderness. It’s a big area and it will swallow you up. It does not care. It will swallow you up and that’s a prime example of just how rugged that terrain is, and how isolated and large it is. So that was a pretty neat experience for me, just to say that we found a missing person and just helped this guy. I think he has a new-found respect for Idaho’s wilderness.

DL: Nice! So you’re mentioning Moose Creek and Three Forks area and one of the things we’re interested in is just the idea of community in this isolated, vast place. What are the gathering places – how do you conceive of the gathering places back there, where people find community?

EM: I would say that the main gathering places that I know of in the Selway-Bitterroot are obviously – the first one being Moose Creek. Which is the prime Ranger Station and administrative site back there. The other ones are probably Horse Camp, just because they use it on the Clearwater as a base for trail crew operations. Shearer, and then the lookouts, of course, but those aren’t really gathering places, I wouldn’t say. The community at Moose Creek is something completely unique that I have never experienced in my life before going back in there. Rob was talking about it at the beginning of the season, and him and I had the chance to fly back there, which was cheating at that time. We flew back there with Bob Schumaker just to see it before we hiked in, to kind of get an idea of the structures and the layout and stuff, and the history. When we hiked in, not only did it feel like we earned the right to be there, but you’re just immersed in this family. Since it is an administrative site, and they run research projects and trail crews, and volunteer and MCC, the Selway-Bitterroot Foundation, I mean, it’s a busy place. It’s a busy place. That is what makes it so great is that everyone is back there for the same reason. They want the wilderness to remain as wild as possible. The only reason that they’re back there and using that site is so that they can access these extremely remote areas. I don’t think nearly any of the work would get done if Moose Creek wasn’t there. The family, like I was saying, it’s completely unique. I long to go there every season, I really do. It’s amazing. You wake up early in the morning and there’s a packer who’s been up since 3:00, 4:00 in the morning. He’s got a pot of the darkest, jet-fueled coffee on the stove and he’s kicked back in a chair, sitting by the fire. He’s just sitting there. You walk in and he grumbles something through his bushely moustache and you go over and get a cup of coffee, and your eyes are all foggy, and people are trickling in. You sit down and maybe play a game of cribbage with the other packer who happens to be there. Then the ranger comes in, and everyone: oh, good morning, good morning, good morning, good morning, good morning! Pancakes start getting fried up, dishes are done and then you’re out in the field, taking down fence and working all day and you’re sweating and your back hurts. Even though airplanes are flying in and it’s just such a unique, like, melting pot. You get so many different user groups in there. There’s just a buzz. There’s an energy and people are excited to be back to be in the place that they love. And that’s just the best feeling ever, because you can’t replace that with anything. You can’t find that anywhere.

DL: So that’s a very different experience than a homecoming in the front country?

EM: Absolutely.

DL: Why?

EM: Because it’s so… The front country is easy. You drive to your home. You ride a bike or whatever. It’s so… it’s what you expect. Getting back into Moose Creek… for one thing, you earn it. You walk back there under your own power, carrying tools and doing work along the way, and when you get back there, not only is it like a sense of accomplishment, but it’s just this, I don’t know, it’s that primordial–your senses are heightened when you’re back there and you become an animal again. Even though you’re at this administrative site. But there’s just something about it, you know? Like you just take, you slow down, and you can appreciate things, and you just become aware of your surroundings and where you are. It doesn’t even compare to being in a city because you have gridded streets. You get back there, and it’s just such a simpler form of life. It really is like taking a step back in time and getting back to the roots of our existence as a species, and part of this community of life.

title: Legends of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Legends of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness,” Jean Carroll recalls stories and legends that populate the backcountry, taking on a life of their own as they pass from campfire to campfire, and are retold on the front porches of log cabins or during breaks along the long trail. Jean Renshaw Carroll is the author of the book, I Never Felt Poor, Except in Town. Selway Saga 1932 to 1948. In her stirring history and memoir, Jean shares about her experiences growing up at Selway Lodge, near the mouth of Bear Creek. She tells lively tales of exploits with her siblings living deep in the wilderness, of the hunters, pilots, trappers, fishermen and guests from all over the country, who visited her family’s home, and of the work she did, helping her father, Alvin Renshaw, with various duties around the ranch and, later, cooking for her brother Jim’s fishing parties. This paragraph is an excerpt from Jean’s book.
Each year, as we rode along the trail, I felt all my senses coming alive to the earthy smells and varied vivid greens of the trees and undergrowth, to the bright yellow patches of the balsamroot, and to the song of the river roaring through canyons or tinkling and murmuring along the deep holes. Always, too, I breathed in that familiar smell of horses and listened to the creak of the saddle leather and clop clop of hooves hitting rock or plopping through mud. Spring runoff all along the watershed would be sending cascades of water off the mountains so that we rode by numerous waterfalls not present any other time of year. As we rode toward our ranch home and simple life on the Selway, I rejoiced again in the fact that I never felt poor, except in town. On the Selway I felt rich… rich in freedom and rich in experience.
From I Never Felt Poor Except in Town, Selway Saga 1932 to 1948 by Jean Carroll and Borg Hendrickson.

orginal_transcript:
Audio Excerpt

Interview with: Jean (Renshaw) Carroll
Interviewers: Debbie Lee, Jane Holman
Location: Red Fir Road, Kooskia, Idaho
Date: February 8, 2011
TOPIC: Legends of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness

DL: Jean has written a book called, I Never Felt Poor, Except In Town, and I was just interested, Jean, if you could talk about your first memories of being back in the wilderness, back at Selway Lodge.

JC: I was sitting in front of Dad in the saddle, going up the trail and feeling very, very tired.

DL: You’ve talked in your book, that there’s certain places like the Salmon hole and Archer’s Grave and Elevator Mountain that kind of held a mystery. Can you talk about that?

JC: Elevator Mountain has a cave, that you can see from the Selway Trail. Well the story was that the Magruder Party, when they were killed, the murderers took some of the gold and hid it in Elevator Cave. But it never looked to me like you could get to it. And you had to… when Punk Wolfinbarger’s wife died, he took her ashes into the cave. Then he died in June and they have taken his ashes to the cave. And from the plane, it did look like there was a sort of a trail there that you could make.

DL: Yeah, do you remember the Magruder story? Do you mind telling it on tape?

JC: Well, Hill Beachy and Magruder were really good friends. Magruder was a merchant and Hill Beachy ran a hotel. Magruder used to go to Virginia City, which I don’t even know where that is. He would take groceries and bring back gold, from wherever. He picked up some guys, to come back with him. They didn’t have pack strings, they just had big bunches of mules, herded, so it took more than one or two people to do it. Then, around the head of the Selway, these people that he had picked up decided they were going to murder Magruder and his people, and so they did. They took the gold, and I heard several stories, that the mules followed, or tried to, so they shot the mules. And I don’t know whether that’s a true story or not. And I don’t know what they did with all the gold. Maybe some went in the cave, maybe not. Anyway, they went back to Lewiston, and the murderer, the main guy, was riding Magruder’s horse. That is the stupidest thing to do, because of course Hill Beachy would recognize it. And besides that, one of the stories is that Hill Beachy had a dream where he saw Magruder killed with an axe. So, if that was true, or maybe it wasn’t true, but just the fact that the guy was riding the horse, and Magruder didn’t come back, made him suspicious. So suspicious, that when these guys left on the boat to go to Portland, or wherever, California, I guess, he followed them and somehow, he got the Sheriff at that place to arrest them and he brought them back. Hill Beachy brought them back. One guy told about it, he wasn’t real smart. So they hung all the rest of them, there in Lewiston. The guy who had provided the evidence, he was dead within a year, drinking or something.

DL: Wow, yeah, I’ve read the story but it sounds very good coming from a local person.

JC: Up Bear Creek, there’s a place we call Salmon Hole, I guess there’s salmon holes up Moose Creek also. But this one, I haven’t been up Moose Creek to see. This one up Bear Creek had what Dad called an oven and he said that the Indians used it. They used to go through there and catch salmon. There used to be a lot of salmon and there is a picture of them as they came back, as they returned. Because there for a long time there weren’t any salmon. When I was little, because they built a dam down at Lewiston. Anyway, I guess they dried or baked the salmon in that oven.

DL: Did you guys go up to the Salmon Hole very often?

JC: Yeah.

DL: Did you ever find any arrowheads or anything?

JC: I never did but other people said they did. I was never looking for arrowheads.

DL: You were just fishing.

JC: Yeah.

DL: Uhm… what about Archer’s Grave? Did you see…

JC: That’s up Running Creek, and of course the story is, Sid Poppe and Sid Poppe is the one that made a cross that said “look before you leap” on it.

DL: And why?

JC: Oh, because he had been, I can’t remember what he had been doing in the wintertime. He was skiing off of that. Maybe he was trapping. He skied the wrong place and went over a bluff. It killed him.

title: Encounters With Animals in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness
introduction:
In this episode, titled “Encounters with Animals in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness,” Jim Renshaw remembers a life spent as a packer and outfitter in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness and the animals that shared a livelihood with him there.

 In 1931 Alvin Renshaw and his wife bought the Pettibone Ranch, which was later renamed Selway Lodge, near the mouth of Bear Creek along the Selway River and just a mile and a half from what would later become Shearer Guard Station. In 1932 Alvin, his wife, and their three small children made their new home deep within what is now the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness. Jim was just two months old at the time. For the next sixteen years the Renshaw family made their living as outfitters, hosting numerous guests from all over the country at the Selway Lodge. Although Alvin sold the business and lodge in 1948, his son Jim began packing for the new owners of the Selway Lodge. Jim later bought an old homestead at Trout Creek, near Three Forks in the Moose Creek drainage, where he and his wife operated an outfitting business in the wilderness. Jim officially retired in 1998, but continues to pack for volunteer trail crews that go into the Selway-Bitterroot yearly for trail maintenance.

orginal_transcript:
Interview with Jim Renshaw
February 8, 2011
Kooskia, Idaho
Interviewed by Debbie Lee and Jane Holman, Moscow, Idaho
TOPIC: Encounters with Animals in the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness

DL: As a packer, and a hunter and, did you ever do any trapping?

JR: Not legally.

DL: But, I mean as someone who’s basically living really close to the land and really close to animals, you know, wild animals as well as domesticated animals. Do you feel like you have a pretty close relationship with animals, and how would you describe that?

JR: Oh definitely. Well, of course, I’m an elk hunter. Elk made my living for me and I love them. I’m real sorry to see we’re losing out on elk. But as far as trapping, the last winter that we stayed in, up there, I wanted to trap. I did, I caught some bobcat. I think I caught three bobcat in the traps, and Dad and I treed a couple with the hounds and got them. Without letting anybody know, I tried to catch a beaver. I didn’t. I mean, I didn’t know how. Did catch one mink, but I had help in setting the trap. I caught a pine squirrel too, but my trapping experience was not much. You know, as far as a feeling toward the animals, yes, I do have feelings toward them. I have compassion, even, for an animal, even though it was my living to see if we couldn’t kill them. I’ve got one particular instance with a bull elk I’ll never forget. I had a hunter up on the hill and the bull come around under us and he shot and wounded it, and so I told him, I says, you stay here and I’ll go chase it down. I was five hours tracking it. It did—It was intelligent. It was thinking. It was an intelligent animal. It got out in the middle of a creek and walked upstream. It did all kinds— it circled me and I never did see it; I was just following the tracks. I finally caught up with it. It got out into a patch of boulders and it had a broken leg, is what it had. But it couldn’t go any farther. It turned around and was popping its teeth at me. It said, I went just as far as I can. Yeah, so I finished it off. And he kind of had the last laugh. That was the first elk I ever had to carry out to my mules, because I couldn’t get my mules in to where he was at, you know. You gotta admire an animal like that. He was doing his best to get away from me.

DL: And your mules. You have had a close relationship with your mules.

JR: Oh yeah, they are kind of like part of the family. I’ve had the opportunity to tell some other people that some people shouldn’t have mules. A mule is a little more intelligent than a horse. And I’ve had horses that I’ve just loved. You just can’t help but do it. I’ve had horses that were just as good as any mule and I’ve had mules that were just as good as any horse. People will say, which one’s the best animal to pack? It depends on the animal entirely. People said, why don’t you ride the mule? Well, I’d rather look at the ears behind me. I won’t argue: Mules can be good saddle animals, but I want to ride a horse and pack a mule. But I’ll pack horses. I’ve had horses that were as good a pack animal as any mule that there ever was, but a mule doesn’t worry, and a horse does. A mule’s going to kind of take care of itself. They’ve got the name of being stubborn. Well, they’re not. They’re smart. You won’t get one of them in trouble, where you can get a horse in trouble. And generally if you’ve got a problem, it’s human-caused, not animal-caused.

DL: So what’s it like to have a mule wreck?

JR: A wreck?

DL: Yeah.

JR: I haven’t had very many. I just haven’t. But it’s pretty bad. I’ve never crippled one of them or anything. I’ve had a couple of them get off the trail and roll down over the hill, but that was actually in the latter part of my time doing it, and part of that was caused because I can’t turn around and look back like I used to. I put a couple of them off – well actually it was a horse and a mule off the trail up on boulder creek because I had them strung out wrong. I had a horse in the lead that if she got her hind leg over the rope, she’d sit down. And I’d had her do it a time or two but it wasn’t bad. Well, anyway, she’d sit down in the wrong spot there. Her and the mule tied to her rolled down over the hill. That was pretty scary but they survived it okay. The other wreck was with a different mule and I don’t know what happened. I looked back and I was short three head. I didn’t know anything had happened. I went back and two of them were standing in the trail, kind of mixed up, but the one mule had rolled down over the hill until it couldn’t roll any farther. It wasn’t hurt any, but I had to go down and take the pack off from it and roll it over and get it up out of there and carry the pack up and put it back on, but I don’t know what caused that. I don’t know.

DL: So, I’ll ask you one final question. This is more of your opinion. Why do you think certain people are drawn to this part of Idaho, the Selway country, the Lochsa country. The Bitterroots.

JR: Probably because they’ve been other places and this is the best place they’ve found.

DL: What does the best place mean?

JR: Fish Lake.

DL: Okay.

JR: I and a couple of other guys did take a week’s trip about ten years ago over onto Big Creek on the Salmon River. I enjoyed that because there were some big meadows. Lots of horse feed. For scenery, the Selway’s got it beat, because you’ve got the rocks and the lakes and stuff like that. And another thing now, the Forest Service fixed the trails up in the Selway to where they are so good. I mean it’s so much better than they were when I started. They used to be, I don’t know how we did it. It was bad.

DL: Okay, well, thank you so much, Jim.

title: Communities of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, Part 1
introduction: “And then I think people get so much out of being in a wilderness setting. Once you take away cars and money and telephones, people are different. And they are different to each other, I think. And then they draw on things in themselves that maybe are a little rusty from our crazy life out here now. I think the ways that people get along when they’re isolated in a place like that, a place that they want to be—it’s a wonderful thing.” ~Sarah Walker Who attached themselves to the Selway-Bitterroot, and why? What about people’s practices and beliefs and their interaction with the land itself preserved its wild character? What do people’s stories tell us about relationships between people and wildland that might be applicable to the future of U.S. wildernesses more broadly? The oral histories gathered for the Selway-Bitterroot History Project will attempt to answer these questions. Such stories are critical to capturing specific fields of information relating to the Selway-Bitterroot. Oral history interviewees include those who were raised on or who owned early homesteads as well as outfitters, packers, trappers, former Fish and Game conservation officers, pilots, early river-runners, smokejumpers, early trail crew members, and wilderness workers. Many lived and worked in the Selway-Bitterroot when the 1964 Wilderness Act was passed and were some of the first people in the U.S. to interpret the legislation as it played out on the ground. In this episode, titled “Communities of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness, part 1,” we hear reminiscences from Sarah Walker who worked for the Forest Service in Idaho and Montana as a Wilderness Ranger from 1977 until 2002 and who was close to the communities of people living in the Selway-Bitterroot wilderness during that time.

Audio Excerpt Transcription:
Interview with Sarah Walker
Moscow, Idaho
December 15, 2010
Interviewed by Debbie Lee and Jane Holman, Moscow, Idaho

SW: The first one I met was the community of the people who lived along the Upper Selway, especially Punk and Carolyn at North Star Ranch. So through them and through that experience, and Freddy and Everett Pierce who lived at Selway Lodge. That was a fascinating thing for me to see how people lived there all year. And I got to go in there because Dick knew those people, and because he could fly there, because the access was by foot or airstrip or plane—and just to see how they how they did day-to-day life was really—I just loved it. There were lots of visitors in the summer and then hunting season was nuts, and then after that things sort of settled down into a dull routine, and I got to go in sometimes then, too, in the winter when the strip was open. And Punk and Carolyn just—they had their wood cook range and their little place where they lived and the low ceiling and the hissing Coleman lantern, and Carolyn made sourdough pancakes right on the top of the metal stove, and she made gallons and gallons of wine from fruit that she picked, and you know when make fruit wine it usually tastes pretty sweet and awful like cough syrup type things, but this wasn’t. It was dry and delicious, and we all drank tons of homemade wine, and Carolyn was a great storyteller. And, isolation meant that she drew stories—she used to memorize the humor sections of the Reader’s Digest and spout this stuff, which sounds funny now to hear, but at the time it was just extraordinary. Anyway, she also wrote poetry, and read a lot of poetry, and she was very widely read. She was a very interesting person. And so, they were sort of the elders of that community. And then younger parts of it, like my niece Sarah Swett worked for Punk and Carolyn. They always had a helper. And then she married a guy named Ian Barlow, and they were caretakers at the Ranch next door called Running Creek. And so they lived there together for four or five years from about 1981 to 85 or so. And then before that, Dolly Carroll–another helper of Punk and Carolyn’–and her husband Alan Carroll lived at Running Creek, and they even got married there and had a wedding there. So part of this community was going in there and going to a wedding in the wilderness. Of course I had already had my own wedding in the Wilderness, but that’s later. So, and we went there for Thanksgiving once to Running Creek. And it was just—once you were there, it was a community feeling, it was—that’s all—those were the only people who were there and you were shut off from the rest of the world in a really remote spot. It was fun.

DL: So are there any examples you can think of besides the wine and the pancakes. It’s food and stories.

SW: Well people loved to go there. And Punk and Carolyn had a lot of friends, and they would come in and see them and come in and stay usually. There were endless stories about a lot people I never met, about old so-and-so, he’s a good old boy, and she’s a pistol. For somebody like me coming from back East this was a real eye-opener, because I had not met people like that–that’s how they were to me in a way, they were these wonderful characters.

DL: Yeah. So you were at the wedding that you mentioned?

SW: Dolly and Allan’s?

DL: Yeah. Can you describe it, something you can remember specifically, or even something that was peculiar or interesting about it that particularly sticks in your mind?

SW: Well, they had, the people who were invited to the wedding were an interesting group because we’d gone in to Punk and Carolyn’s the day before or something, and stayed up late the night before, and I’m sure mourning Dolly’s marriage because everybody loved Dolly—ahhhh. So by the time the day of the wedding came we were all kind of shot, but we did hike over there, and Running Creek Ranch is another small, low-ceiling building, spick-and-span inside with a polished–old, but polished up–wood range to cook on in the kitchen, and this little kitchen and not much room in there. And everybody’s all shined up for the wedding. And there was a minister who flew in. I don’t remember how that worked, I don’t remember that, but…
